headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Mead Johnson Nutrition Earnings Conference Call. My name is Derek and I'll be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to Kathryn Chieger, Vice Pr
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Mead Johnson Nutrition Earnings Conference Call. My name is Derek and I'll be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to Kathryn Chieger, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please proceed Katherine.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to Mead Johnson's Fourth Quarter Conference Call, which happens to be my 125th and last quarterly earnings announcement. As many of you know, I will be retiring next week, and I want to say how much I've enjoyed sharin
componenttext: Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to Mead Johnson's Fourth Quarter Conference Call, which happens to be my 125th and last quarterly earnings announcement. As many of you know, I will be retiring next week, and I want to say how much I've enjoyed sharing the Mead Johnson stories with all of you this past two years. Let now turn the call over to my friend, colleague and successor, Kathy MacDonald, who'll have the pleasure of hosting her first earnings call. Kathy?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathryn. One of my early learnings is to be respectful of investors time. So, I'll turn to the business at hand. With me today are Steve Golsby, our CEO; and Pete Leemputte, our CFO.Before we get started, let me remind everyone that our comme
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathryn. One of my early learnings is to be respectful of investors time. So, I'll turn to the business at hand. With me today are Steve Golsby, our CEO; and Pete Leemputte, our CFO.
Before we get started, let me remind everyone that our comments will include forward-looking statements about our future results, including statements about our financial prospects and projections, new product launches and market conditions that constitute forward-looking statements for purposes of the Safe Harbor provisions under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Keep in mind that our actual results may differ materially from expectations as of today due to various factors, including those listed in our annual report on Form 10-K for 2009, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K and registration statements in each case, as filed with or furnished to the Securities and Exchange Commission and our earnings release issued this morning, all of which are available upon request or on our website at meadjohnson.com.
In addition, any forward-looking statements represent our estimates only as of today and should not be relied on as representing our estimates as of any subsequent date. While we may elect to update forward-looking statements at some point in the future, we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so even if our estimates change. Given that we are in the midst of the earnings reporting season, we will keep our call to 45 minutes. 
That said, I will turn the call over to Steve.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathy, and good morning, everyone. As you read in our press release, we concluded our 2010 on a very strong note and delivered another year of record sales and earnings. Non-GAAP earnings of $0.57 per share in the fourth quarter were up 19% fro
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathy, and good morning, everyone. As you read in our press release, we concluded our 2010 on a very strong note and delivered another year of record sales and earnings. Non-GAAP earnings of $0.57 per share in the fourth quarter were up 19% from 2009 bringing our full-year EPS to $2.42 per share up 9% from the prior year. We accomplish many important goals in 2010, the most notable of which include over 9% constant dollar sales growth, the highest level scene in the last five years. Most encouragingly, it was 5% volume growth that drove the global sales increase. The increase was led by our Asia/Latin America segment which posted 16% growth excluding foreign exchange. We invested heavily behind advertising and promotion and in sales force expansion in the key gross market, which led to solid market share gains across the American market of Asia and Latin America. Our 
U.S. business grew despite continued decline in the first and formula consumption, fueled by successful new product launches including our patented Jewel prebiotics, unique packaging system and a newborn product formulated for the first three months of life.
In June, we launched our first joint venture as a public company with Almarai, the leading regional food and dairy producer serving markets in the Middle East. Sales into the market started in the fourth quarter, although we are still in an investment mode with this JV, this demonstrates our commitment to fueling long-term growth and expanding Mead Johnson's global presence. 
Sales outside the U.S. came to represent 68% of the company total up from 65% in 2009, and 62% in 2008. We opened a new Pediatric Nutrition Institute or PNI in Evansville, Indiana, which gives us the capability of scaling up new manufacturing processes without disrupting our operating plans. We also broke ground on a new PNI in Guangzhou, China, which is set to open later this year and service base of product government in this critical market. 
We set new productivity record that helped to mitigate the impact of higher dairy and commodity cost on our gross margins. We set our earnings record while absorbing a $24 million hit from the January 2010 devaluation of the Venezuelan bolivar, along with the $11 million in incremental non-cash pension expense and $18 million in shares service cost overland. And as a result of our November 2009 debt refinancing, interest expense was nearly cut in half and we drove further reductions in our effective tax rate from 30% in 2009 to only 29% in 2010 both contributing strongly to our earnings improvement.
Finally, we made significant progress in building our stand-alone infrastructure, establishing critical capabilities necessary for us to operate independently. Following significant actions by our large number of our associates around the world, we completed the design of our global SAP technology platform during 2010. And went live with the new system in North America during the fourth quarter.
Let's now turn our focus to our regional segments. The impressive growth in Asia and Latin America was led by China and Hong Kong which together, reported sales of $745 million in 2010 and now account to 24% of our global revenues. By the end of 2010, we were fully resort in a 193 cities in china. In 2011, we expect to expand our China geographic footprint into additional 50 cities through our disciplined set change programs. In our Asia/Latin America growth beyond china. We saw strong gains in many markets including Malaysia and Singapore, as well as in key Latin America markets such as Mexico, Brazil, Colombia and Peru. 
Earlier this month I traveled to Mexico City, where I have the pleasure of opening our new Latin American regional headquarters office, as well as our new Latin America Pediatric Nutrition Institute. This is our third PNI research facility. Our important investment in Latin America will help accelerate our growth and allows strengthen innovation and product development for infants and children in the region. 
Those in the United States increased 5% in the fourth quarter partially offset by a declining euro. I'll talk about our U.S. business in more details shortly but let me the first highlight some of the factors that influenced sales in Europe, which account for about 4% of our global business. 
The decline in Europe was largely attributable to the timing of shipments into certain markets. However, we are seeing some evidence in the drop of birthrates in key markets like Spain, but particularly important to us. Further there's a shift to the lower price food store channel away from pharmacist, where our infant formula Nutramigen and other specialty products are sold. Turning back to the U.S., we're pleased with the 5% sales growth in the quarter. That's solid progress compared to that 3% real growth we delivered in the third quarter particularly in light of the continued drop in the overall U.S. market. The CDC recently released new information that indicates that U.S. births were down 4% in the first half of 2010 relative to the first half of 2009. That's an acceleration from the 2.6% drop seen in 2009. WIC infant front participation data is more current and is now available through October 2010.
The data shows the birth is still declining with lower WIC infant participation in the third and early fourth quarters.
Lowest consumption from extended breast-feeding or earliest transition to cow's milk is also being seen. We continue to believe that the U.S. birthrate will ultimately rebound. There are signs of an improving economy that will ultimately lead to higher birth. The continued high unemployment in the U.S., as well as the natural lag between planning a pregnancy and the birth would suggest that birth will decline in 2011, and that we won't see any recovery until 2012 at the earliest. The contraction in the U.S. market has massed the continued gain in our market share during the fourth quarter that we started to see following the product and packaging innovation launched in the second and third quarters, along with the spike due to competitive product recoil late September. That competitor is now back on show, but we currently expect 2011 market share on average to be higher than2010 and offset a lower number of birth and reduced formula consumption.
Let's turn our attention to our outlook for 2011. We expect to produce another year of sales and earnings growth, and are initiating  2011 non-GAAP EPS guidance in the range of $2.55 to $2.65, up from $2.42 per share in 2010.
These assumptions underlying these non-GAAP estimate include a sales increases of 7% to 8% excluding foreign exchange. At this early point in the year, we anticipate that the top line growth will be more heavily weighted towards volume than price. Finally, you will see us continuing increase investments behind demand generation and new products innovation to fuel future growth.
I'll turn the call over to Pete to provide you further highlights and we'll return to wrap up and take your questions.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to start our 2010 financial results and provide some color on cash flow and also a bit more detail on 2011. Since Steve covered sales growth by segment, let me focus on the cost and margin side of the
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to start our 2010 financial results and provide some color on cash flow and also a bit more detail on 2011. Since Steve covered sales growth by segment, let me focus on the cost and margin side of the equation. First, our gross margin in the fourth quarter was 62.3%, down from the 63.4% reported both in the third quarter and on a full-year basis. 
Higher dairy and commodity cost were at work. We saw soft prices for milk increased during the second quarter and it takes about six months for these to work through our cost of good sold. our children's attrition product, largely sold in Asia and Latin America, contain a higher percentage of dairy by weight . and a impact is more pronounced under this emerging market segment.
In 2011, commodity costs are expected to increase on average in the high single-digits. Led by higher dairy prices, other agricultural raw materials, and packaging.
Over the last two months, we've seen milk price increases of 5% to as much as 15%. We expect this balance, higher commodity cost with strong productivity in some pricing resulting in gross margin averaging 63.5% in line with 2010.
Operating expenses reached almost 41% of sales in the fourth quarter. The highest level of any quarter this past year and above the 39.4% for the full-year. The shares of this cost overlap came in at $11 million, more than double the level of payment in the third quarter. As a reminder, this overlap represent the temporary duplication of the IT, finance and indirect procurement costs, as we transition from Bristol-Myers Squibb to IBM. We 
successfully launched SAP in our North American market and as a result, started to use IBM service to a greater extent during the fourth quarter. We will roll out SAP in our international market throughout 2011 and charges from IBM will increase as a result. 
On a full-year basis, the overlap is expected to grow from $18 million in 2010 to as much as $24 million in 2011 causing us about $0.02 in earnings.
We expect to be completely off the Bristol-Myers share service in IT technology platform by the end of this year.
Our total share service costs overlap over 2010 and 2011 is expected to fall in the range of $40 million to $42 million in line with our prior projection.
While operating expenses will be stressed a bit by the increase of shared service costs and a few other item, I'll discuss in a minute, we will start to leverage over G&A structure in 2011. While allowing for continued high levels of investment and demand generation.
We expect total operating expenses to center around 39.5% of sales. We will see greater G&A leverage reflected in 2012 and beyond after the completion of our SAP projects.
Let me highlight the overall impact from foreign exchange in our financial results. In 2010, sales increased by 2% for the full year from foreign exchange. The biggest contributor was the weakening of the dollar, most notably in Asia. This favorable impact was muted by the January 2010 devaluation of the Venezuelan bolivar that took a full point of our sales growth over the course of the year, and reduced earnings on a pretax basis by $24 million versus 2009 or $0.08 per share.
Unfortunately, we are facing further headwinds from the bolivar as we enter 2011. In last year's devaluation, the Venezuelan government introduced a dual exchange rate. The first rate for the 2.6 bolivars per dollar was for importing essential goods, including much of our product line. The second, set at 4.3 bolivars per dollar applied to all other good, as well as profits realized in country.
In December 31st, Venezuela eliminated the Dual rate structure and converged the essentials rate to 4.3 bolivars per dollar. 
You will see $0.02 of reduced earnings in 2011 relative to 2010 just from this section alone
Please note that under current market rate, foreign exchange should add about a point and a half to top line growth in 2011.
After the bolivar exchange rate unification, the bottom line impact is a $0.01 or $0.02 of additional earning.
As Steve mentioned earlier, lower interest expense and a reduced tax rate contributed to earnings growth for 2010. We refinanced our debt in late 2009 and also swapped $700 million of our $1.5 billion in six rate notes of floating interest rates. This swaps allowed us to benefit from the low interest rate environment in 2010. When rates starting to rise, we took advantage of the appreciative value of the swap and then $100 million in the fourth quarter.
Interest expense should increase from $49 million into the low to mid-$50 million range, depending on weather we unwind the $500 million and remaining six floating interest swaps.
Turning to our balance sheet. We ended the year with $596 million in cash. Up $35 million from December of 2009. That's after retiring $120 million in debt outstanding against our revolving credit facility in the first quarter, $50 million in contribution to our frozen defined benefit pension plan in the U.S., a dividend increase of 12.5% and $172 million in cash use for capital expenditures, up 80% versus 2009.
Investments in our IT technology platform and new packaging lines were the key driver of the increase. Note that on an accrued basis, reflecting actual work performed during the year, capital spending was $143 million consistent with our $150 million guidance. Accrued capital expenditures for 2011 are currently expected to be about $125 million. Capital spending necessary for our SAP build out will continue through the year. Importantly, there are two non-cash expenses that will reduce earnings per share by a total of $0.09 in 2011 relative to 2010. First, depreciation and amortization expense totaled $65 million in 2010. We expect that to grow to $75 million, largely as a result of our capital investment in IT. The majority of the $10 million DNA increase, which equates to about $0.04 per share will be seen in operating expenses, as our new IT system support many business processes like sales management, order to cash, accounting and indirect procurement.
Secondly, non-cash compensation expense will perform its base equity reward would increase from $20 million to about $35 million, equivalent to another $0.05 in earnings per share. The majority of our annual equity awards are in the form of option and performance share. With the expense recognized over their three-year vesting period.
As each year has passed since our 2009 IPO, we recognize the expense from an additional award. Though the buildup to three-full years of equity award from 2009, 2010, and 2011 will be reflected in stock-based compensation expense for the first time. Our higher stock price is also a factor. Note that we should not see increases in equity expense of this magnitude in 2012 and beyond with our current three-year equity award cycle.
We made solid progress in 2010 managing controllable working capital, which we defined as trade receivable, inventory and accounts payable. Given our high growth rate, we measure ourselves and percentage of sales basis checkout. We reduced average working capital to 8.7% of sales in 2010 from 12.4% in 2009 and almost 15% in 2008.
This strong result will deliver us inventory and accounts payable management received strong focus and help us achieve performance significantly better than the 11.4% average seen by our peers.
Let me wrap up my prepared remarks by pointing out the detail on our initial 2011 non-GAAP earnings guidance of $2 and $0.55 to $2 and $0.65 per share. This is based on constant dollar sales growth of 7% to 8% with midteen in Asia and Latin America and low-single-digit growth in North America euro. Foreign exchange would add another 1.5% at today's rates. We are currently assuming gross margin to center around 63.5% in line with 2010. 
Operating expenses measured as a percent of sale should be relatively flat at about 39.5% after absorbing $0.09 in added non-cash expense for G&A along with equity-based compensation. 
And finally, the effective tax rate for 2011 is expected to fall between 28% and 29%. All in all, we've targeted another strong year of performance. Before I turn the call back to Steve, let me offer my thanks to Kathryn for her dedication service to Mead Johnson. She's done a great job establishing and leading our Investor Relations function over the past two years.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pete. First, I also want to personally thank Kathryn for her excellent work over the last couple of years, and wish her well in her retirement. I'd like to conclude by acknowledging the ethics of all our Mead Johnson colleagues around the glo
componenttext:
Thank you, Pete. First, I also want to personally thank Kathryn for her excellent work over the last couple of years, and wish her well in her retirement. 
I'd like to conclude by acknowledging the ethics of all our Mead Johnson colleagues around the global, who delivered such a strong performance in 2010. I know that they share my commitment for our mission, our strategy and ensuring that we continue to drive sustainable, profitable growth in 2011. And I'll be pleased to take your questions. To give everyone an opportunity to participate, we request that you ask just one question and if necessary, a follow-up and then we'll pass it along to the next person in the queue. Operator please open the line for questions.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  And the first question comes from the line of Ed Aaron with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  And the first question comes from the line of Ed Aaron with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow-up a little bit on your Europe. How are you planning for that business going forward since it seems there have been somewhat meaningful change and be real change among consumers that develop in the quarter, and can you just give us a se
componenttext: I wanted to follow-up a little bit on your Europe. How are you planning for that business going forward since it seems there have been somewhat meaningful change and be real change among consumers that develop in the quarter, and can you just give us a sense of -- just with the inventory, I know you talked about taking $10 million out there in the quarter, how did that shake out? And then what are the expectations for destocking in Europe in 2011, and does the change in the market dynamics affect the amount that you're looking to take out of inventory ahead of the transition of your distribution?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first part of the question and then Pete can cover your question on the new trends. As I mentioned in the script that Europe accounts for about 4% of our business. The business has grown over time but represents a lower proportion of sales a
componenttext: I'll take the first part of the question and then Pete can cover your question on the new trends. As I mentioned in the script that Europe accounts for about 4% of our business. The business has grown over time but represents a lower proportion of sales and the consequence of the rapid growth in our Asia/Latin American businesses. We have a very strong position in the algae management sector particularly with our new brand. And we have a growing presence in a few selected markets in the premium routine and some formula segment. Nevertheless, the region is seeing many of the same fundamental changes that we've seen in North America with lower birth, and lower consumption. It's also a very competitive region and as you stated Ed, there is something of a shift due to the challenging economy from the pharmacist to the food channel, where lower-price offerings are available. We will continue to evolve our strategy and our business model. In 2011 we riveted on the transformation to the new SAP technology platform to the new distributor program model. And ensuring that we continue to grow the core parts of our business in selected areas. But don't expect it to increase as a proportion of our business in the foreseeable future. Pete, do you want to take with the inventory point?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ed, you're completely correct. We have indicated last quarter that we were expecting about a $10 million or $11 million inventory adjustment coming in the fourth quarter. This is different than what we saw in the prior year, we're moving, we're installing
componenttext: Ed, you're completely correct. We have indicated last quarter that we were expecting about a $10 million or $11 million inventory adjustment coming in the fourth quarter. This is different than what we saw in the prior year, we're moving, we're installing SAP, we're moving to our on distribution away from BMS. And we're going to hold more than inventory essentially as opposed to our customers. As it turned out, the actual decline in the quarter was in the midteens in Q4. In that account for a majority of the decrease, if you look at the segment sales for North America and Europe, in Q4 versus Q3 that is the key big driver there.

componenttext: Just a question on the guidance for next year which Steve and Pete, I guess you're aware, it's lower than the market is expecting. But the guidance also leads me to believe that this may be a much greater year of the investing in the business and perhaps some people expect it. Can you help me a little bit with that question, perhaps in terms of what you're planning to spend on marketing, what the various innovation cost maybe? I assume that you would continue along the innovation platform, just along that general questions, just what kind of investment year is this for you guys?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Stephen, you're certainly right that we're continuing to invest significantly in the growth of the business. Our investment, our planned investment in advertising, promotions, salesforce and R&D will rise appropriately in line with our sales growt
componenttext: This is Stephen, you're certainly right that we're continuing to invest significantly in the growth of the business. Our investment, our planned investment in advertising, promotions, salesforce and R&D will rise appropriately in line with our sales growth. We're making important investments in a number of new geographies. I mentioned, our joint venture in the Middle East, we've also have spoken in the times about the geographic expansion in China and about the investment we are making in India, Brazil and Russia. So all of those businesses show very exciting long-term potential. But we're clearly in an investment mode for the next few years.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

componenttext: The other point I would make, Terry too is we've been talking to about the shared service overlap cost. We started out the year expecting them to be between $25 million, last quarter talked about the $20 million and that came in at $18 million. The total cost has not changed but there ahs been a shift to more of that spending coming through in 2011. So as they say, that could be up as much a $6 million year-on-year and that's another factor I look.

componenttextpreview: I guess my question kind of is a following up on Terry's. You've mentioned a bit on the pricing front but, I think historically when we talked about the outlook for pricing him a you've been a bit more cautious then you've seem to indicated today. Given t
componenttext: I guess my question kind of is a following up on Terry's. You've mentioned a bit on the pricing front but, I think historically when we talked about the outlook for pricing him a you've been a bit more cautious then you've seem to indicated today. Given the weakness, I guess, in the U.S. market and the fact that the industry or the category has raised price prices pretty aggressively. So, I'm just kind of wondering if there a bit of conservatism in terms of how much pricing you really expected versus the inflation rate, and is that the cause in part due for the margins to kind of be flat in your '11 guidance?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think that isn't what we tried to communicate. Within the sales guidance that we've given you, I indicated that, that would be weighted towards volumes.  The mix between volume and price as in 2010 is going to be 2/3 towards volume, 1/3 towards price so
componenttext: I think that isn't what we tried to communicate. Within the sales guidance that we've given you, I indicated that, that would be weighted towards volumes.  The mix between volume and price as in 2010 is going to be 2/3 towards volume, 1/3 towards price something of that nature. We're not planning significant price increases. We continue to look at multiple factors market by market to determine our pricing strategies. And the gross margins, we're able to guide you towards flat gross margins principally as a result of our best in class productivity programs.

componenttext: Want to move my questions over to North America/Europe segment, really specifically the United States. And here your most updated comments on the effect of the recall. Honestly, when I look at the segment sales, I think you've explained that the segment itself came in below our expectations. And I think the answer to what you're saying was Europe is the area of the weakness. In the United States, do you expect --  well, first of, can you quantify what you think the benefit was of the recall? And the same point on that same topic is, do you think you can hold on to those sales? And if I could just add one further  point to put all of the pieces of the question in play, what did Abbott do during the quarter in order to retain customers, I think it was all about lowering pricing on the ready to drink product, and I want to know what kind of effect they're pricing strategy has on Mead?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: David, let me take first part of the question and then I'll turn it over to Steve. With regard to the impact in the U.S. and market share, we believe if you look at Nielsen data, that you all can access to, it looks that we picked up about 2.5 points of m
componenttext: David, let me take first part of the question and then I'll turn it over to Steve. With regard to the impact in the U.S. and market share, we believe if you look at Nielsen data, that you all can access to, it looks that we picked up about 2.5 points of market share in the fourth quarter relative to the third quarter. Now, you can't separate out how much of that is coming from the recall, how much of that is coming from our product innovation. Both our network and as you recall, in the third quarter we mentioned we were seeing share gains prior to their recall checkout. But if you look at the market on a retail basis it's roughly $2.5 billion to 2.5% of that would imply something on the order of $6 million annually or on the quarterly basis about $15 million. So that's the impact that market share as we would see in retail in the fourth quarter.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

componenttext: As we indicated on the last call, Abbott's principal actions were to drive consumers both towards the smaller pack sizes of their similar order product, which as you know stores from a different manufacturing plant and we're not affected and towards their liquid products. And they did a very good job of that. The pricing action that they took, you're absolutely right, was on their liquid products. So they drop the price of liquid such that an equivalent feeding would cost what it would have done with had powders have been fully available and we followed that action to make sure that our liquids were competitive. We are, as they are now fully back in the market, we are not seeing any unanticipated or extraordinary pricing actions that clearly seeking to rebuild the equity of the business where it's been impacted. And we're very confident in the program that we have in place and innovations that introduced doors back in our 2010. We are seeing I'm sure from our Nielsen data improvement in our market share of between 2% 3% to the fourth quarter and we expect to be able to hold an improved market share through 2011 take a.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Mead Johnson Nutrition Q4 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Derrick and I’ll be your coordinator for today. (Operator instructions) As a reminder this conference call is being recorded for replay purposes. I would now like to turn the presentation over to Kathryn Chieger, Vice President Investor Relations. Please proceed, Kathryn.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you and good morning. Welcome to Mead Johnson’s Q4 conference call, which happens to be my 125th and last quarterly earnings announcement. As many of you know I will be retiring next week and I want to say how much I’ve enjoyed sharing the Mead
componenttext: Thank you and good morning. Welcome to Mead Johnson’s Q4 conference call, which happens to be my 125th and last quarterly earnings announcement. As many of you know I will be retiring next week and I want to say how much I’ve enjoyed sharing the Mead Johnson story with all of you these past two years. Let me know turn the call over to my friend, colleague, and successor Kathy McDonald, who will have the pleasure of hosting her first earnings call. Kathy?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathryn. One of my early learnings is to be respectful of investors’ time so I’ll turn to the business at hand. With me today are Steve Golsby, our CEO, and Pete Leemputte, our CFO.Before we get started let me remind everyone that our com
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathryn. One of my early learnings is to be respectful of investors’ time so I’ll turn to the business at hand. With me today are Steve Golsby, our CEO, and Pete Leemputte, our CFO.
Before we get started let me remind everyone that our comments will include forward-looking statements about our future results including statements about our financial prospects and projections, new product launches and market conditions that constitute forward-looking statements for the purposes of the Safe Harbor Provision under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Keep in mind that our actual results may differ materially from expectations as of today due to various factors including those listed in our annual reports on Form 10K for 2009, quarterly reports Form 10Q, current reports on Form 8K, and registration statements - in each case as filed with or furnished to the Securities and Exchange Commission - and our earnings release issued this morning, all of which are available upon request or on our website at MeadJohnson.com. In addition, any forward-looking statements represent our estimates only as of today and should not be relied on as representing our estimates as of any subsequent date. While we may elect to update forward-looking statements at some point in the future, we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so even if our estimates change.
Given that we are in the midst of the earnings reporting season we will keep our call to 45 minutes. That said I will turn the call over to Steve.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathy, and good morning, everyone. As you read in our press release we concluded 2010 on a very strong note and delivered another year of record sales and earnings. Non-GAAP earnings of $0.57 per share in the Q4 were up 19% from 2009 brining ou
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathy, and good morning, everyone. As you read in our press release we concluded 2010 on a very strong note and delivered another year of record sales and earnings. Non-GAAP earnings of $0.57 per share in the Q4 were up 19% from 2009 brining our full year EPS to $2.42 per share, up 9% from the prior year. We accomplished many important goals in 2010, the most notable of which include over 9% constant dollar sales growth, the highest level seen in the last five years. Most encouragingly, it was 5% volume growth that drove the global sales increase. The increase was led by our Asia/Latin America segment, which posted 16% growth excluding foreign exchange.
We invested heavily behind advertising and promotion and in sales force expansion in key growth markets, which led to solid market share gains across the emerging markets of Asia and Latin America. Our US business grew despite continued declines in both births and formula consumption fueled by successful new product launches including our patented dual prebiotics, unique packaging system, and a newborn product formulated for the first three months of life.
In June we launched our first joint venture as a public company with Almarai, the leading regional food and dairy producer serving markets in the Middle East. Sales into the markets started in the Q4. Although we are still in an investment mode with this JV, this demonstrates our commitment to fueling long-term growth and to expanding Mead Johnson’s global presence. Sales outside the US came to represent 68% of the company’s total, up from 65% in 2009 and 62% in 2008.
We opened a new pediatric nutrition institute, or PNI, in Evansville, Indiana, that gives us the capability of scaling up new manufacturing processes without disrupting our operating plans. We also broke ground on a new PNI in Guangzhou, China, which is set to open late this year and serve as a base for product development in this critical market. We set new productivity records that helped to mitigate the impact of higher dairy and commodity costs on our gross margins. We set our earnings record while absorbing a $24 million hit from the January, 2010, devaluation of the Venezuelan Bolivar along with $11 million in incremental, non-cash pension expense and $18 million in shared service costs overlap. And, as a result of our November, 2009, debt refinancing, interest expense was nearly cut in half and we drove further reductions in our effective tax rate from 30% in 2009 to under 29% in 2010, both contributing strongly to our earnings improvement.
Finally, we made significant progress in building our standalone infrastructure, establishing critical capabilities necessary for us to operate independently. Following significant effort by a large number of our associates around the world, we completed the design of our global SAP technology platform during 2010 and went live with the new system in North America during the Q4.
Let’s now turn our focus to our regional segments. The impressive growth in Asia and Latin America was led by China and Hong Kong, which together reported sales of $745 million in 2010, and now account for 24% of our global revenues. By the end of 2010 we were fully resourced in 193 cities in China. In 2011 we expect to expand our China geographic footprint into an additional 50 cities through our disciplined step change program. But our Asia/Latin America growth goes beyond just China. We saw strong gains in many markets including Malaysia and Singapore as well as in key Latin American markets such as Mexico, Brazil, Colombia, and Peru.
Earlier this month I traveled to Mexico City where I had the pleasure of opening our new Latin America regional headquarters office as well as our new Latin America pediatric nutrition institute. This is our third PNI research facility. Our important investments in Latin America will help accelerate our growth and allow us to strengthen innovation and product development for infants and children in the region.
Sales in the United States increased 5% in the Q4, partially offset by a decline in Europe. I’ll talk about our US business in more detail shortly, but let me first highlight some of the factors that influenced sales in Europe, which account for about 4% of our global business. The decline in Europe was largely attributable to the timing of shipments in certain markets. However, we are seeing some evidence of a drop in the birth rate in some key markets like Spain that are particularly important to us. Further, there is a shift to the lower-priced food store channel away from pharmacies where our infant formula, Nutramigen and other specialty products are sold.
Turning back to the US, we’re pleased with the 5% sales growth in the Q4. That’s solid progress compared to the 3% real growth we delivered in the Q3, particularly in light of the continued drop in the overall US market. The CDC recently released new information that indicates that US births were down 4% in the first half of 2010 relative to the first half of 2009. That’s an acceleration from the 2.6% drop seen in 2009. WIC infant participation data is more current, and is now available through October of 2010. The data shows that births are still declining with lower WIC infant participation in the Q3 and early Q4. Lower consumption from extended breastfeeding or earlier transition to cow’s milk is also being seen.
We continue to believe that the US birth rate will ultimately rebound. There are signs of an improving economy that should ultimately lead to higher births, but continued high unemployment in the US as well as the natural lag between planning a pregnancy and the birth will suggest that births will decline in 2011 and that we won’t see any recovery until 2012 at the earliest. The contraction in the US market has masked the continued gain in our market share during the Q4 that we started to see following the product and package innovations launched in the Q2 and Q3, along with a spike due to a competitor’s product recall in late September. That competitor is now back on-shelf but we currently expect 2011 market share on average to be higher than 2010 and offset a lower number of births and reduced formula consumption.
Let’s now turn our attention to our outlook for 2011. We expect to produce another year of sales and earnings growth and are initiating 2011 non-GAAP EPS guidance in the range of $2.55 to $2.65, up from $2.42 per share in 2010. The assumptions underlying this non-GAAP estimate include a sales increase of 7% to 8% excluding foreign exchange. At this early point in the year we anticipate that the top line growth will be more heavily weighted towards volume than price. Finally, you will see us continue to increase investments to (inaudible) demand generation and new product innovation to fuel future growth.
I’ll now turn the call over to Pete to provide you further highlights and then we’ll return to wrap up and take your questions.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, and good morning everyone. I’d like to start with our 2010 financial results, provide some color on cash flow and also a bit more detail on 2011.As Steve covered sales growth by segment, let me focus on the costs and margins out of the
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve, and good morning everyone. I’d like to start with our 2010 financial results, provide some color on cash flow and also a bit more detail on 2011.
As Steve covered sales growth by segment, let me focus on the costs and margins out of the equation. First, our gross margin in the Q4 was 62.3%, down from the 63.4% reported both in the Q3 and on a full-year basis. Higher dairy and commodity costs were at work. We saw spot prices for milk increase during the Q2, and it takes about six months for these to work through our cost of goods sold. Our children’s nutrition products, largely sold in Asia and Latin America, contain a higher percentage of dairy by weight so the impact was more pronounced on this emerging market segment. In 2011, commodity costs are expected to increase on average in the high single digits, led by higher dairy prices, other agricultural raw materials, and packaging. Over the last two months we’ve seen milk price increases of 5% to as much as 15%. We expect to balance higher commodity costs with strong productivity and some pricing, resulting in gross margins averaging 63.5% in line with 2010.
Operating expenses reached almost 41% of sales in the Q4, the highest level of any quarter this past year, and above the 39.4% for the full year. The shared service cost overlap came in at $11 million, more than double the level seen in the Q3. As a reminder, this overlap represents the temporary duplication of IT, Finance, and indirect procurement costs as we transition from Bristol Meyers Squibb to IBM. We successfully launched SAP in our North American markets, and as a result started to use IBM services to a greater extent during the Q4. We will roll out SAP in our international markets throughout 2011 and charges from IBM will increase as a result. On a full-year basis, the overlap is expected to grow from $18 million in 2010 to as much as $24 million in 2011, costing us about $0.02 in earnings. We expect to be completely off the Bristol Meyers shared service and IT technology platform by the end of this year. Our total shared service cost overlap over 2010 and 2011 is expected to fall in the range of $40 million to $42 million, in line with our prior projections. While operating expenses will be stressed a bit by the increase in shared service costs and a few other items I’ll discuss in a minute, we will start to leverage our G&A structure in 2011 while allowing for continued high levels of investment and demand generation. We expect total operating expenses to center around 39.5% of sales. We will see greater G&A leverage reflected in 2012 and beyond after the completion of our SAP projects.
Let me highlight the overall impact from foreign exchange on our financial results. In 2010 sales increased by 2% for the full year from foreign exchange. The biggest contributor was the weakening of the dollar, most notably in Asia. This favorable impact was muted by the January, 2010, devaluation of the Venezuelan Bolivar, which took a full point off our sales growth over the course of the year and reduced earnings on a pre-tax basis by $24 million versus 2009, or $0.08 per share. Unfortunately we are facing further headwinds from the Bolivar as we enter 2011. In last year’s devaluation, the Venezuelan government introduced a dual exchange rate. The first rate, set at 2.6 Bolivars per dollar, was for importing essential goods including much of our product line. The second, set at 4.3 Bolivars per dollar, applied to all other goods as well as profits realized in-country. On December 31st, Venezuela eliminated the dual rate structure and converged the essentials rate to 4.3 Bolivars per dollar. We will see $0.02 of reduced earnings in 2011 relative to 2010 just from this action alone. Please note that under current market rates, foreign exchange should add about a point and a half to top line growth in 2011. After the Bolivar exchange rate unification, the bottom line impact is a penny or two of additional earnings.
As Steve mentioned earlier, lower interest expense and a reduced tax rate contributed to earnings growth in 2010. We refinanced our debt in late 2009 and also swapped $700 million of our $1.5 billion in fixed rate notes to floating interest rates. These swaps allowed us to benefit from the low interest rate environment in 2010. When rates started to rise we took advantage of the appreciated value of the swaps and unwound $200 million in the Q4. Interest expense should increase from $49 million into the low- to mid-$50 million range, depending on whether we unwind the $500 million in remaining fixed-to-floating interest rate swaps.
Turning to our balance sheet, we ended the year with $596 million in cash, up $35 million from December of 2009. That’s after retiring $120 million in debt outstanding against our revolving credit facility in the Q1, $50 million in contributions to our frozen defined benefit pension plan in the US, a dividend increase of 12.5%, and $172 million in cash used for capital expenditures, up 80% versus 2009. Investments in our IT technology platform and new packaging lines were the key drivers of the increase. Note that on an accrued basis reflecting actual (inaudible) performed during the year, capital spending was $143 million, consistent with our $150 million guidance. Accrued capital expenditures for 2011 are currently expected to be about $125 million. Capital spending necessary for our SAP build-out will continue through the year.
Importantly, there are two non-cash expenses that will reduce earnings per share by a total of $0.09 in 2011 relative to 2010. First, depreciation and amortization expense totaled $65 million in 2010. We expect that to grow to $75 million, largely as a result of our capital investments in IT. A majority of the $10 million G&A increase, which equates to about $0.04 per share, will be seen in operating expenses as our new IT systems support many business processes like sales management, order to cash, accounting, and indirect procurement. Secondly, non-cash compensation expense through performance-based equity awards, will increase from $20 million to about $35 million, equivalent to another $0.05 in earnings per share. The majority of our annual equity awards are in the form of options and performance shares, with the expense recognized over their three-year vesting period. As each year has passed since our 2009 IPO, we’ve recognized the expense from an additional award, so the buildup to three full years of equity awards from 2009, 2010, and 2011 will be reflected in stock-based compensation expense for the first time. Our higher stock price is also a factor. Note that we should not see increases in equity expense of this magnitude in 2012 and beyond with our current three-year equity award cycle.
We made solid progress in 2010 managing controllable working capital, which we define as trade receivables, inventory, and accounts payable. Given our high growth rates we measure ourselves on a percentage of sales basis. We reduced average working capital to 8.7% of sales in 2010, from 12.4% in 2009 and almost 15% in 2008. These strong results were delivered as inventory and accounts payable management received strong focus and helped us achieve performance significantly better than the 11.4% average seen by our peers.
Let me wrap up my prepared remarks by pulling together the details on our initial 2011 non-GAAP earnings guidance of $2.55 to $2.65 per share. This is based on constant dollar sales growth of 7% to 8% with mid-teen growth in Asia/Latin America and low single-digit growth in North America/Europe. Foreign exchange would add another 1.5% at today’s rates. We are currently assuming gross margins to center around 63.5% in line with 2010. Operating expenses measured as a percent of sales should be relatively flat at about 39.5% after absorbing $0.09 in added non-cash expense for G&A along with equity-based compensation. And finally, the effective tax rate for 2011 is expected to fall between 28% and 29%. All in all we’ve targeted another strong year of performance.
Before I turn the call back over to Steve, let me offer my thanks to Kathryn for her dedicated service to Mead Johnson. She’s done a great job establishing and leading our investor relations function over the last two years.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pete. Of course I also want to personally thank Kathryn for her excellent work over the last couple of years and wish her well in her retirement. I’d like to conclude by acknowledging the efforts of all our Mead Johnson colleagues around the
componenttext:
Thank you, Pete. Of course I also want to personally thank Kathryn for her excellent work over the last couple of years and wish her well in her retirement. I’d like to conclude by acknowledging the efforts of all our Mead Johnson colleagues around the globe who delivered such strong performance in 2010. I know that they share my commitment to our mission, our strategy, and to ensuring that we continue to drive sustainable, profitable growth in 2011.
We will now be pleased to take your questions. To give everyone an opportunity to participate we request that you ask just one question, and if necessary a follow-up, and then we will pass it along to the next person in the queue. Operator, please open the lines for questions.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, we are now ready to open the lines to your questions. (Operator Instructions) Please standby for your first question. The first question comes from the line of Ed Aaron with RBC Capital Markets. You may proceed.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, we are now ready to open the lines to your questions. (Operator Instructions) Please standby for your first question. The first question comes from the line of Ed Aaron with RBC Capital Markets. You may proceed.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks for taking the questions. I wanted to follow up a little bit on Europe. How are you planning for that business going forward since it seems to have been a somewhat meaningful change, a behavioral change that developed among consumers in the quarter
componenttext: Thanks for taking the questions. I wanted to follow up a little bit on Europe. How are you planning for that business going forward since it seems to have been a somewhat meaningful change, a behavioral change that developed among consumers in the quarter? And then if you could just give us a sense of just what the inventory- I know you had talked about taking 10 million out there in the quarter. How did that shake out and then what are the expectations for destocking in Europe in 2011, and does the change in the market dynamics affect the amount that you’re looking to take out of inventory ahead of the transition of your distribution? Thanks.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ed, I’ll take the first part of the question and then Pete can cover your question on inventories. As I mentioned in the script that Europe accounts for about 4% of our business. The business has grown over time but represents a lower proportion of sale
componenttext: Ed, I’ll take the first part of the question and then Pete can cover your question on inventories. As I mentioned in the script that Europe accounts for about 4% of our business. The business has grown over time but represents a lower proportion of sales as a consequence of the rapid growth in our Asia/Latin American businesses. We have a very strong position in the allergy management sector, particularly with our Nutramigen brand, and we have a growing presence in a few selected markets in the premium routine infant formula segment. Nevertheless, the region is seeing many of the same fundamental changes that we see in North America, with lower births and lower consumption. It’s also a very competitive region, and as you stated, Ed, there is something of a shift due to the challenging economy from the pharmacies to the food channel where lower priced offerings are available. We will continue to evolve our strategy and our business model. In 2011 we’re riveted on the transformation to the new SAP technology platform, to the new distributor program and model, and to ensuring that we continue to grow the core parts of our business in selected areas. But don’t expect it to increase as a proportion of our business in the foreseeable future. Pete, do you want to take the inventory point?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. Ed, you’re completely correct. We had indicated last quarter that we were expecting about a $10 million or $11 million inventory adjustment coming in the Q4. This is different than what we saw in the prior year. We’re installing SAP, we’re mov
componenttext: Sure. Ed, you’re completely correct. We had indicated last quarter that we were expecting about a $10 million or $11 million inventory adjustment coming in the Q4. This is different than what we saw in the prior year. We’re installing SAP, we’re moving to our own distribution away from BMS, and we’re going to hold more of that inventory centrally as opposed to our customers. As it turned out, the actual decline in the quarter was in the mid-teens in Q4, and that accounts for a majority of the decrease. If you look at the segment sales for North America and Europe in Q4 versus Q3, that is the key big driver there.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great, thank you. Kathryn, congrats and good luck.
componenttext: Great, thank you. Kathryn, congrats and good luck.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ed.
componenttext: Thanks, Ed.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, very good. Just a question on the guidance for next year, which Steve and Pete, I guess you’re aware it’s lower than what the market was expecting. Now I do understand the additional costs in the operating expenses due to the compensation, due t
componenttext: Okay, very good. Just a question on the guidance for next year, which Steve and Pete, I guess you’re aware it’s lower than what the market was expecting. Now I do understand the additional costs in the operating expenses due to the compensation, due to the depreciation. But your guidance also leads me to believe that this may be a much greater year of investing in the business than perhaps some people expected. Can you help me a little bit with that question perhaps in terms of what you’re planning to spend on marketing, what the various innovation costs may be? I assume that you would continue along the innovation platform… Just along the general questions of just what kind of investment year is this for you guys?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Terry, you’re certainly right that we’re continuing to invest significantly in the growth of the business. Our investments, our planned investments in advertising, promotions, sales force and R&D, will rise approximately in line with our sales growth.
componenttext: Terry, you’re certainly right that we’re continuing to invest significantly in the growth of the business. Our investments, our planned investments in advertising, promotions, sales force and R&D, will rise approximately in line with our sales growth. We’re making important investments in a number of new geographies. I mentioned the joint venture in the Middle East; you’ve also heard us talk many times about the geographic expansion in China and about the investments we’re making in India, Brazil, and Russia. So all of those businesses show very exciting, long-term potential, but we’re clearly in an investment mode for the next few years.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The other point I would make, Terry, too, is we’ve been talking to you about the shared service overlap costs. We started out the year expecting them to be $25 million; last quarter I talked about $20 million and it came in at $18 million. The total cos
componenttext: The other point I would make, Terry, too, is we’ve been talking to you about the shared service overlap costs. We started out the year expecting them to be $25 million; last quarter I talked about $20 million and it came in at $18 million. The total cost has not changed but there has been a shift to more of that spending coming through in 2011, so as I say that could be up you know, as much as $6 million in the new year and that’s another factor at work.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

componenttext: Okay, very good. Thank you.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Hi, good morning, everybody. Kathryn, good luck. I guess my question, kind of following up on Terry’s, is you mentioned a bit on the pricing front but I think historically when we’ve talked about the outlook for pricing you’ve been a bit more cautio
componenttext: Hi, good morning, everybody. Kathryn, good luck. I guess my question, kind of following up on Terry’s, is you mentioned a bit on the pricing front but I think historically when we’ve talked about the outlook for pricing you’ve been a bit more cautious than you seem to have indicated today, given the weakness I guess in the US market and the fact that the industry or the category has raised prices pretty aggressively. So I’m just kind of wondering is there a bit of conservatism in terms of how much pricing you really expected versus the inflation rate, and is that the cause in part for the margins to kind of be flat in your ‘11 guidance? Thanks.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I think that isn’t what we tried to communicate. Within the sales guidance that we’ve given you I indicated that that would be weighted towards volume. The mix between volume and price, as in 2010, is going to be two thirds towards volume, a third
componenttext: No, I think that isn’t what we tried to communicate. Within the sales guidance that we’ve given you I indicated that that would be weighted towards volume. The mix between volume and price, as in 2010, is going to be two thirds towards volume, a third towards price, that nature. We’re not planning significant price increases. We continue to look at multiple factors market by market to determine our pricing strategies. And you know, the gross margins, we’re able to guide you toward flat gross margins principally as a result of our best in class productivity programs.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you for the clarification; I’ll pass it on.
componenttext: Okay. Thank you for the clarification; I’ll pass it on.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I want to move my questions over to North America/Europe segment, really specifically the United States, and hear your most updated comments on the effect of the recall. Honestly when I looked at the segment sales I think you explained that - the segment
componenttext: I want to move my questions over to North America/Europe segment, really specifically the United States, and hear your most updated comments on the effect of the recall. Honestly when I looked at the segment sales I think you explained that - the segment came in below our expectations. I think the answer, what you were saying is Europe was the area of the weakness. In the United States, do you expect- Well first off, would you quantify what you think the benefit was of the recall? And then the second point on that same topic is do you think you can hold onto those sales? And if I could just add one further point to put all of the pieces of the question in play, what did Abbott do during the quarter in order to retain customers? I think it was all about lowering pricing on their ready-to-drink product and I want to know what kind of effect their pricing strategy has on Mead. Thank you.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, David. Let me take the first part of the question and then I’ll turn it over to Steve. With regard to the impact in the US and market share, we believe- If you look at Nielsen data that you all can have access to, it looks like we picked up about
componenttext: Sure, David. Let me take the first part of the question and then I’ll turn it over to Steve. With regard to the impact in the US and market share, we believe- If you look at Nielsen data that you all can have access to, it looks like we picked up about two and a half points of market share in the Q4 relative to the Q3. Now, we can’t separate out how much of that is coming from the recall, how much of that is coming from our product innovation; both are at work. And as you recall, in the Q3 we mentioned we were seeing share gains prior to their recall. But if you look at the market on a retail basis it’s roughly $2.5 billion. 2.5% of that would imply something on the order of $60 million annually, or on a quarterly basis about $15 million. So that’s the impact of market share that we would see at retail in the Q4.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: David, as we indicated on the last call, Abbott’s principle actions were to drive consumers both towards the smaller pack sizes of their Similac powder products, which as you know are sourced from a different manufacturing plant and were not affected; a
componenttext:
David, as we indicated on the last call, Abbott’s principle actions were to drive consumers both towards the smaller pack sizes of their Similac powder products, which as you know are sourced from a different manufacturing plant and were not affected; and towards their liquid products. And they did a very good job of that. The pricing actions that they took, you’re absolutely right, was on their liquid products. So they dropped the price of liquids such that an equivalent feeding would cost what it would have done had powders been fully available, and we followed that action to make sure our liquids were competitive.
As they are now fully back in the market we are not seeing any unanticipated or extraordinary pricing actions. They’re clearly seeking to rebuild the equity of the business where it’s been impacted. And we’re very confident in the programs that we have in place and the innovations that we introduced toward the backend of 2010. We are seeing, as you are I’m sure from your Nielsen data, an improvement in our market share of between 2% and 3% in the Q4, and we expect to be able to hold an improved market share through 2011.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great, I really appreciate the thoroughness of the answer. Thank you.
componenttext: Great, I really appreciate the thoroughness of the answer. Thank you.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

componenttext: Thanks, David.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning and let me add my congratulations and thanks to Kathryn, all the way back to Kraft I think, in ‘85 or something. So shifting to the market that really drives it, China - you know, it’s easy for us to agonize about details in the US but th
componenttext: Good morning and let me add my congratulations and thanks to Kathryn, all the way back to Kraft I think, in ‘85 or something. So shifting to the market that really drives it, China - you know, it’s easy for us to agonize about details in the US but the Chinese market is really you know, it’s a story. And I guess I really don’t have a sense of the competitive landscape and what’s happening there. We really do understand that march to greater penetration of cities, but would you mind providing a little more detail on competitive activity there and how you’re faring against other major operators?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yeah, thanks Tim. We grew share significantly in China through 2010, not only as a consequence of our step change program but more importantly as a consequence of growing penetration and consumption in our core cities. Around three quarters of the growth
componenttext: Yeah, thanks Tim. We grew share significantly in China through 2010, not only as a consequence of our step change program but more importantly as a consequence of growing penetration and consumption in our core cities. Around three quarters of the growth that we recorded last year came from the core cities that we’re established in, and only a quarter from the improved presence in the step change cities. We don’t, as you know, talk about market share data explicitly on a country basis, but I can tell you that we are the number one by value in China currently. If you combine it with Hong Kong that number one status is underlined, and overall we would say 50% of our annual growth came from a market share improvement for the year, and perhaps as much as 75% of our Q4 growth from market share. So we’re seeing tremendous momentum that gives us great confidence for the future.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: That’s very helpful. Thanks so much.
componenttext: That’s very helpful. Thanks so much.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Vincent Andrews from Morgan Stanley. Please proceed.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you and again, congratulations to Kathryn. Thank you for all the help. I’ll ask a question on China as well: you talked about entering fifty new cities this year, and I think if I wrote down correctly the number you’re already in coming into ‘
componenttext: Thank you and again, congratulations to Kathryn. Thank you for all the help. I’ll ask a question on China as well: you talked about entering fifty new cities this year, and I think if I wrote down correctly the number you’re already in coming into ‘11 is 183. And just if you could give us some granularity of number or percentage of cities that as of the end of last year, as of the end of 2010, you were fully into, because presumably you’re not entering all 50 cities, you didn’t enter into all 50 cities in 2011 on Jan. 1. So I’m just trying to get a sense of what are you carrying over into 2011 that’s not already integrated from 2010; or even I don’t know if you go back to 2009 in some areas. But just if that makes sense can you help me out there?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The number was 193, Vincent, at year end. We have a very disciplined approach to this program and we do make sure that before we move on to a new city that we are fully established and are meeting or exceeding very precise and demanding metrics of perform
componenttext: The number was 193, Vincent, at year end. We have a very disciplined approach to this program and we do make sure that before we move on to a new city that we are fully established and are meeting or exceeding very precise and demanding metrics of performance, because the last thing we want to do is spread our resources too thinly and fail to execute with excellence. So that expansion will be somewhat continuous; it’ll be backend weighted in 2011. I don’t expect a year from now to be saying anything very different from what I’m saying now - three quarters or more of our growth will come from cities in which we’re fully established, and a quarter or a little less from new cities. In fact, we discussed our China business yesterday with our Board of Directors and you know, without giving too much away I can say that there are many other waves of step change in the pipeline. And though there aren’t any more Beijing’s, Shanghai’s and Guangzhou’s to come along, you know, we’re still talking about very substantial cities that will allow us to increase penetration and presence for many years to come.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would also just add, Vincent, that in terms of the timing as we move through the year - if that’s part of your question, too - the additional cities that we moved into tended to get to a fully staffed position the second half of the year, probably on
componenttext: I would also just add, Vincent, that in terms of the timing as we move through the year - if that’s part of your question, too - the additional cities that we moved into tended to get to a fully staffed position the second half of the year, probably on average.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, but just as a follow-up, that 193 you consider fully established today? Is that correct?
componenttext: Okay, but just as a follow-up, that 193 you consider fully established today? Is that correct?

componenttextpreview: We do, yes.
componenttext: We do, yes.

componenttext: Okay. Thank you very much.

componenttextpreview: This is [Fisher], I was hoping to give one to Pete, here. Can you just talk a little bit more about how we’re thinking about the cash balance looking into 2011 and your incremental cash flow? I know CAPEX is stepping down a bit this year. Are you guys l
componenttext: This is [Fisher], I was hoping to give one to Pete, here. Can you just talk a little bit more about how we’re thinking about the cash balance looking into 2011 and your incremental cash flow? I know CAPEX is stepping down a bit this year. Are you guys looking to maybe build on your whitespace expansion to the Russia’s, the India’s, the Brazil’s of the world with maybe some tack-on acquisitions? Or should we start seeing more cash back to shareholders this year? Can you just frame that up for us a bit?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yeah, it’s very difficult as you might imagine, sitting back and saying when any particular deal or transaction might occur. But I think we certainly our considering M&A as one avenue for growth for the company, and we get great returns from organic gro
componenttext: Yeah, it’s very difficult as you might imagine, sitting back and saying when any particular deal or transaction might occur. But I think we certainly our considering M&A as one avenue for growth for the company, and we get great returns from organic growth but that is something that we can flush out and that we’ll continue to put some emphasis on in the new year. In terms of our cash flow overall it’s obviously very strong. We still have high capital spending in 2011. The other thing I would point out, too, is we’ve said in terms of our share repurchase program, where we have $300 million authorized by the Board, that the purpose of that program is to help offset dilution that may come from equity awards to employees. And as we’ve discussed those have not had a big impact if you look over the last year but they could have a bigger impact as we move through the new year, and that’s something that we’ll be considering as well.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I want to add just a real quick follow-on if I could. I guess you’re saying “no comment” but any chance you guys are taking a look at small businesses that are for sale in India?
componenttext: I want to add just a real quick follow-on if I could. I guess you’re saying “no comment” but any chance you guys are taking a look at small businesses that are for sale in India?

componenttext: Sure. The only thing that would come to mind easily would be in the US. When you look at the first, the comparisons are going to be a little bit easier on average in the first half of the year; a little bit tougher because of the share gains that we had in the second half of the year. headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
