headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Hi, thank you. Congratulations, Kathryn. You talked a lot about these PNI’s that you’re building out and they’re in Mexico and Guangzhou, maybe not in Mexico but in Evansville. How do you balance off having kind of just one pilot plant - I imagine t
componenttext: Hi, thank you. Congratulations, Kathryn. You talked a lot about these PNI’s that you’re building out and they’re in Mexico and Guangzhou, maybe not in Mexico but in Evansville. How do you balance off having kind of just one pilot plant - I imagine they’re pilot plants - having one in Indiana versus building them in the countries where you’re operating? How does being closer to the local market help your R&D efforts, and I guess satisfy the local needs?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: That’s a great question, thank you. Just to clarify, only in Evansville, Indiana, do we have the scalable pilot plant that I referred to that allows us to research and develop manufacturing processes without shutting down our manufacturing facilities. O
componenttext: That’s a great question, thank you. Just to clarify, only in Evansville, Indiana, do we have the scalable pilot plant that I referred to that allows us to research and develop manufacturing processes without shutting down our manufacturing facilities. Our motto is, in simple terms, centralized research and discovery, decentralized product development. The product development we believe happens best closest to the consumer. Remember, a lot of our business in Asia/Latin America is in the children’s nutritional area, where tastes and offerings differ significantly. We also believe it drives speed; we also believe there’s a benefit in being close to the regulators in the regions and the markets to accelerate the pace and effectiveness of our innovations. So we don’t plan to build any more in the foreseeable future. Our network will consist of these three pediatric nutrition institutes and a centralized research function.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can I ask a follow-up, Steve? Just I always think of Nestle as having a dominant business in Latin America, and I think Mead is kind of a second- or third-tier player. Do you foresee more market share gains in those markets and how do you compete against
componenttext: Can I ask a follow-up, Steve? Just I always think of Nestle as having a dominant business in Latin America, and I think Mead is kind of a second- or third-tier player. Do you foresee more market share gains in those markets and how do you compete against a company like that that just seems to have the dominant share?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: We’re- I won’t be defensive about your comment, calling it second- or third-tier. We’re truly excited about the current growth performance of our Latin American businesses where I think every market last year in local currency grew in strong double
componenttext: We’re- I won’t be defensive about your comment, calling it second- or third-tier. We’re truly excited about the current growth performance of our Latin American businesses where I think every market last year in local currency grew in strong double digits. We have very strong market shares in a number of areas, in a number of countries, but most exciting is the fact that the category is growing extremely strongly. Consumers, healthcare professionals are more aware of the importance of early life nutrition, fundamentally favorable economics and demographics. We’re investing very heavily in those businesses, in infrastructure, demand creation. We’re putting particular emphasis on Brazil and in fact, Brazil was on a percentage basis our fastest growing business in 2010. And yes, you’re right - Nestle has been in the region for a long time, they have a very large presence, but this is a growth category just as it was and is in China. If you went back far enough, Nestle would have been the dominant player in China and that isn’t the case today. So we believe that with better offerings, better science, our proven business model we can be extremely successful over a long period of time.

componenttext: You know, it’s been running relatively consistently as you mentioned, roughly $12 million a quarter. And we do expect an increase into the low- to mid-50’s. We did unwind that $200 million swap, which proved by the way to be quite effective for us. It had $20 million in value, $20 million in cash roughly that we brought in. And accounting basically dictates that that gain is amortized over the remaining life of the debt, so you don’t see as much of an impact as you would… It’ll still be there but it’ll be showing up over time. I would think that it should be reasonably consistent quarter by quarter throughout the year at this point.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to Mead Johnson's Fourth Quarter Conference Call, which happens to be my 125th and last quarterly earnings announcement. As many of you know, I will be retiring next week, and I want to say how much I've enjoyed sharin
componenttext: Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to Mead Johnson's Fourth Quarter Conference Call, which happens to be my 125th and last quarterly earnings announcement. As many of you know, I will be retiring next week, and I want to say how much I've enjoyed sharing the Mead Johnson stories with all of you this past two years. Let now turn the call over to my friend, colleague and successor, Kathy MacDonald, who'll have the pleasure of hosting her first earnings call. Kathy?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathryn. One of my early learnings is to be respectful of investors time. So, I'll turn to the business at hand. With me today are Steve Golsby, our CEO; and Pete Leemputte, our CFO.Before we get started, let me remind everyone that our comme
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathryn. One of my early learnings is to be respectful of investors time. So, I'll turn to the business at hand. With me today are Steve Golsby, our CEO; and Pete Leemputte, our CFO.
Before we get started, let me remind everyone that our comments will include forward-looking statements about our future results, including statements about our financial prospects and projections, new product launches and market conditions that constitute forward-looking statements for purposes of the Safe Harbor provision under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Keep in mind that our actual results may differ materially from expectations as of today due to various factors, including those listed in our annual report on Form 10-K for 2009, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K and registration statements in each case, as filed with or furnished to the Securities and Exchange Commission and our earnings release issued this morning, all of which are available upon request or on our website at meadjohnson.com.
In addition, any forward-looking statements represent our estimates only as of today and should not be relied on as representing our estimates as of any subsequent date. While we may elect to update forward-looking statements at some point in the future, we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so even if our estimates change. Given that we are in the midst of the earnings reporting season, we will keep our call to 45 minutes. 
That said, I will turn the call over to Steve.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathy, and good morning, everyone. As you read in our press release, we concluded 2010 on a very strong note and delivered another year of record sales and earnings. Non-GAAP earnings of $0.57 per share in the fourth quarter were up 19% from 20
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathy, and good morning, everyone. As you read in our press release, we concluded 2010 on a very strong note and delivered another year of record sales and earnings. Non-GAAP earnings of $0.57 per share in the fourth quarter were up 19% from 2009 bringing our full-year EPS to $2.42 per share up 9% from the prior year. We accomplish many important goals in 2010, the most notable of which include over 9% constant dollar sales growth, the highest level scene in the last five years. Most encouragingly, it was 5% volume growth that drove the global sales increase. The increase was led by our Asia/Latin America segment which posted 16% growth excluding foreign exchange. We invested heavily behind advertising and promotion and in sales force expansion in the key gross markets, which led to solid market share gains across the American markets of Asia and Latin America. 
Our U.S. business grew despite continued decline in both birth and formula consumption, fueled by successful new product launches including our patented Jewel prebiotics, unique packaging system and a newborn product formulated for the first three months of life.
In June, we launched our first joint venture as a public company with Almarai, the leading regional food and dairy producer serving markets in the Middle East. Sales into the market started in the fourth quarter, although we are still in an investment mode with this JV, this demonstrates our commitment of fueling long-term growth and expanding Mead Johnson's global presence. 
Sales outside the U.S. came to represent 68% of the company total, up from 65% in 2009 and 62% in 2008. We opened a new Pediatric Nutrition Institute or PNI in Evansville, Indiana, that gives us the capability of scaling up new manufacturing processes without disrupting our operating plans. We also broke ground on a new PNI in Guangzhou, China, which is set to open late this year and serve as a base of product development in this critical market. 
We set new productivity records that helped to mitigate the impact of higher dairy and commodity cost on our gross margins. We set our earnings record while absorbing a $24 million hit from the January 2010 devaluation of the Venezuelan bolivar, along with the $11 million in incremental non-cash pension expense and $18 million in shares service cost overlap. And as a result of our November 2009 debt refinancing, interest expense was nearly cut in half and we drove further reductions in our effective tax rate from 30% in 2009 to only 29% in 2010 both contributing strongly to our earnings improvement.
Finally, we made significant progress in building our stand-alone infrastructure, establishing critical capabilities necessary for us to operate independently. Following significant effort by a large number of our associates around the world, we completed the design of our global SAP technology platform during 2010. And went live with the new system in North America during the fourth quarter.
Let's now turn our focus to our regional segments. The impressive growth in Asia and Latin America was led by China and Hong Kong which together, reported sales of $745 million in 2010 and now account to 24% of our global revenues. By the end of 2010, we were fully resort in a 193 cities in china. In 2011, we expect to expand our China geographic footprint into an additional 50 cities through our disciplined step change program. And our Asia/Latin America growth beyond just china. We saw strong gains in many markets including Malaysia and Singapore, as well as in key Latin America markets such as Mexico, Brazil, Colombia and Peru. 
Earlier this month I traveled to Mexico City, where I had the pleasure of opening our new Latin-American regional headquarters office, as well as our new Latin America Pediatric Nutrition Institute. This is our third PNI research facility. Our important investment in Latin America will help accelerate our growth and allow us to strengthen innovation and product development for infants and children in the region. 
Those in the United States increased 5% in the fourth quarter partially offset by a decline in Europe. I'll talk about our U.S. business in more details shortly but let me the first highlight some of the factors that influenced sales in Europe, which account for about 4% of our global business. 
The decline in Europe is largely attributable to the timing of shipments in certain markets. However, we are seeing some evidence in the drop of in the birthrate in key markets like Spain, that are particularly important to us. Further, there is a shift to the lower-price food store channel away from pharmacist, where our infant formula Nutramigen and other specialty products are sold. 
Turning back to the U.S., we're pleased with the 5% sales growth in the quarter. That's solid progress compared to the 3% real growth we delivered in the third quarter particularly in light of the continued drop in the overall U.S. market. The CDC recently released new information that indicates that U.S. births were down 4% in the first half of 2010 relative to the first half of 2009. That's an acceleration from the 2.6% drop seen in 2009. WIC infant participation data is more current and is now available through October 2010. The data shows the birth is still declining with lower WIC infant participation in the third and early fourth quarters.
Lower consumption from extended breast-feeding or earlier transition to cow's milk is also being seen. We continue to believe that the U.S. birthrate will ultimately rebound. There are signs of an improving economy that should ultimately lead to higher birth. The continued high unemployment in the U.S., as well as the natural lag between planning a pregnancy and the birth would suggest that birth will decline in 2011 and that we won't see any recovery until 2012 at the earliest. 
The contraction in the U.S. market has massed the continued gain in our market share during the fourth quarter that we started to see following the product and packaging innovations launched in the second and third quarters, along with the spike due to our competitive product recoil late September. That competitor is now back on show, but we currently expect 2011 market share on average to be higher than 2010 and offset a lower number of births and reduced formula consumption.
Let's now turn our attention to our outlook for 2011. We expect to produce another year of sales and earnings growth, and are initiating  2011 non-GAAP EPS guidance in the range of $2.55 to $2.65, up from $2.42 per share in 2010.
The assumptions underlying these non-GAAP estimate  include a sales increase of 7% to 8% excluding foreign exchange. At this early point in the year, we anticipate that the top line growth will be more heavily weighted towards volume than price. 
Finally, you will see us continuing increase investments behind demand generation and new product innovation to fuel future growth.
I'll turn the call over to Pete, to provide you further highlights and we'll return to wrap up and take your questions.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to start with our 2010 financial results, provide some color on cash flow and also a bit more detail on 2011. Since Steve covered sales growth by segment, let me focus on the cost and margin side of the
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to start with our 2010 financial results, provide some color on cash flow and also a bit more detail on 2011. Since Steve covered sales growth by segment, let me focus on the cost and margin side of the equation. 
First, our gross margin in the fourth quarter was 62.3%, down from the 63.4% reported both in the third quarter and on a full-year basis. Higher dairy and commodity costs were at work. We saw spot prices for milk increase during the second quarter and it takes about six months for these to work through our cost of good sold. Our children's nutrition product, largely sold in Asia and Latin America, contain a higher percentage of dairy by weight. While the impact was more pronounced on this emerging market segment.
In 2011, commodity costs are expected to increase on average in the high single-digits. Led by higher dairy prices, other agricultural raw materials and packaging.
Over the last two months, we've seen milk price increases of 5% to as much as 15%. We expect this balance, higher commodity cost with strong productivity in some pricing resulting in gross margins averaging 63.5% in line with 2010.
Operating expenses reached almost 41% of sales in the fourth quarter. The highest level of any quarter this past year and above the 39.4% for the full-year. The shares of this cost overlap came in at $11 million, more than double the level seen in the third quarter. As a reminder, this overlap represents the temporary duplication of the IT, finance and indirect procurement costs, as we transition from Bristol-Myers Squibb to IBM. 
We successfully launched SAP in our North American markets and as a result, started to use IBM services to a greater extent during the fourth quarter. We will roll out SAP in our international markets throughout 2011, and charges from IBM will increase as a result. 
On a full-year basis, the overlap is expected to grow from $18 million in 2010 to as much as $24 million in 2011, costing us about $0.02 in earnings. We expect to be completely off the Bristol-Myers share service in IT technology platform by the end of this year.
Our total share service cost overlap over 2010 and 2011 is expected to fall in the range of $40 million to $42 million in line with our prior projection.
While operating expenses will be stressed a bit by the increase in share of service costs and a few other items, I'll discuss in a minute, we will start to leverage over G&A structure in 2011. While allowing for continued high levels of investment and demand generation.
We expect total operating expenses to center around 39.5% of sales. We will see greater G&A leverage reflected in 2012 and beyond after the completion of our SAP projects.
Let me highlight the overall impact from foreign exchange on our financial results. In 2010, sales increased by 2% for the full year from foreign exchange. The biggest contributor was the weakening of the dollar, most notably in Asia. This favorable impact was muted by the January 2010 devaluation of the Venezuelan bolivar that took a full point of our sales growth over the course of the year and reduced earnings on a pretax basis by $24 million versus 2009 or $0.08 per share.
Unfortunately, we are facing further headwinds from the bolivar as we enter 2011. In last year's devaluation, the Venezuelan government introduced a dual exchange rate. The first rate for the 2.6 bolivars per dollar was for importing essential goods, including much of our product line. The second, set at 4.3 bolivars per dollar applied to all other goods, as well as profits realized in country.
In December 31st, Venezuela eliminated the dual-rate structure and converged the essentials rate to 4.3 bolivars per dollar. You will see $0.02 of reduced earnings in 2011 relative to 2010 just from this section alone.
Please note that under our current market rate, foreign exchange should add about a point and a half to top line growth in 2011.  After the bolivar exchange rate unification, the bottom line impact is a $0.01 or $0.02 of additional earning.
As Steve mentioned earlier, lower interest expense and a reduced tax rate contributed to earnings growth for 2010. We refinanced our debt in late 2009 and also swapped $700 million of our $1.5 billion in six rate notes of floating interest rates. This swaps allowed us to benefit from the low interest rate environment in 2010. When rates start to surmise, we took advantage of the appreciative value of the swap and unwound $200 million in the fourth quarter.
Interest expense should increase from $49 million into the low to mid-$50 million range, depending on weather we unwind the $500 million and remaining six defloating interest swaps.
Turning to our balance sheet. We ended the year with $596 million in cash. Up $35 million from December of 2009. That's after retiring $120 million in debt outstanding against our revolving credit facility in the first quarter, $50 million in contribution to our frozen defined benefit pension plan in the U.S., a dividend increase of 12.5% and $172 million in cash use for capital expenditures, up 80% versus 2009. Investments in our IT technology platform and new packaging lines were the key drivers of the increase. 
Note that on an accrued basis, reflecting actual work performed during the year, capital spending was $143 million consistent with our $150 million guidance. Accrued capital expenditures for 2011 are currently expected to be about $125 million. Capital spending necessary for our SAP build out will continue through the year. 
Importantly, there are two non-cash expenses that will reduce earnings per share by a total of $0.09 in 2011 relative to 2010. First, depreciation and amortization expense totaled $65 million in 2010. We expect that to grow to $75 million, largely as a result of our capital investments in IT. The majority of the $10 million DNA increase, which equates to about $0.04 per share, will be seen in operating expenses as our new IT system support many business processes like sales management, order to cash, accounting and indirect procurement.
Secondly, non-cash compensation expense will perform its base equity wards will increase from $20 million to about $35 million, equivalent to another $0.05 in earnings per share. The majority of our annual equity awards are in the form of option and performance shares. With the expense recognized over their three-year vesting period.
As each year has passed since our 2009 IPO, we recognize the expense from an additional award. Though the buildup to three-full years of equity awards from 2009, 2010, and 2011 will be reflected in stock-based compensation expense for the first time. Our higher stock price is also a factor. Note that we should not see increases in equity expense of this magnitude in 2012 and beyond with our current three-year equity award cycle.
We made solid progress in 2010 managing controllable working capital, which we defined as trade receivable, inventory and accounts payable. Given our high growth rates, we measure ourselves in a percentage of sales basis. We reduced average working capital to 8.7% of sales in 2010 from 12.4% in 2009 and almost 15% in 2008.
This strong results were delivered as inventory and accounts payable management received strong focus and help us achieve performance significantly better than the 11.4% average seen by our peers.
Let me wrap up my prepared remarks by pulling together the details on our initial 2011 non-GAAP earnings guidance of $2 and $0.55 to $2 and $0.65 per share. This is based on constant dollar sales growth of 7% to 8% with mid-teen growth in Asia, Latin America and low-single-digit growth in North America, Europe. Foreign exchange would add another 1.5% at today's rates. We are currently assuming gross margin to center around 63.5% in line with 2010. 
Operating expenses, measured as a percent of sale should be relatively flat at about 39.5% after absorbing $0.09 in added non-cash expense for G&A along with equity-based compensation. 
And finally, the effective tax rate for 2011 is expected to fall between 28% and 29%. All in all, we've targeted another strong year of performance. Before I turn the call back to Steve, let me offer my thanks to Kathryn for her dedicated service to Mead Johnson. She's done a great job establishing and leading our Investor Relations function over the past two years.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pete. First, I also want to personally thank Kathryn for her excellent work over the last couple of years, and wish her well in her retirement. I'd like to conclude by acknowledging the efforts of all our Mead Johnson colleagues around the gl
componenttext:
Thank you, Pete. First, I also want to personally thank Kathryn for her excellent work over the last couple of years, and wish her well in her retirement. 
I'd like to conclude by acknowledging the efforts of all our Mead Johnson colleagues around the globe, who delivered such strong performance in 2010. I know that they share my commitment through our mission, our strategy and ensuring that we continue to drive sustainable, profitable growth in 2011. And we'll now be pleased to take your questions. To give everyone an opportunity to participate, we request that you ask just one question and, if necessary, a follow-up and then we will pass it along to the next person in the queue. 
Operator please open the line for questions.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  And the first question comes from the line of Ed Aaron with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  And the first question comes from the line of Ed Aaron with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow-up a little bit on Europe. How are you planning for that business going forward? Because there seems to have been somewhat meaningful change and behavioral change among consumers that developed in the quarter, and can you just give us a
componenttext: I wanted to follow-up a little bit on Europe. How are you planning for that business going forward? Because there seems to have been somewhat meaningful change and behavioral change among consumers that developed in the quarter, and can you just give us a sense of -- just with the inventory, I know you talked about taking $10 million out there in the quarter, how did that shake out? And then what are the expectations for destocking in Europe in 2011, and does the change in the market dynamics affect the amount that you're looking to take out of inventory ahead of the transition of your distribution?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ed, I'll take the first part of the question and then Pete can cover your question on the inventory. As I mentioned in the script that Europe accounts were about 4% of our business. The business has grown over time but represents a lower proportion of sal
componenttext: Ed, I'll take the first part of the question and then Pete can cover your question on the inventory. As I mentioned in the script that Europe accounts were about 4% of our business. The business has grown over time but represents a lower proportion of sales as the consequence of the rapid growth in our Asia/Latin-American businesses. We have a very strong position in the allergy management sector, particularly with our Nutramigen brand. And we have a growing presence in a few selected markets in the premium routine and some formula segment. Nevertheless, the region is seeing many of the same fundamental changes that we see in North America with lower birth, and lower consumption. It's also a very competitive region and as you stated, Ed, there is something of a shift due to the challenging economy from the pharmacist to the food channel, where lower-price offerings are available. We will continue to evolve our strategy and our business model. In 2011 we riveted on the transformation to the new SAP technology platform to the new distributor program model. And ensuring that we continue to grow the core parts of our business in selected areas. But don't expect it to increase as a proportion of our business in the foreseeable future. Pete, do you want to take with the inventory point?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ed, you're completely correct. We had indicated last quarter that we were expecting about a $10 million or $11 million inventory adjustment coming in the fourth quarter. This is different than what we saw in the prior year, we're moving, we're installing
componenttext: Ed, you're completely correct. We had indicated last quarter that we were expecting about a $10 million or $11 million inventory adjustment coming in the fourth quarter. This is different than what we saw in the prior year, we're moving, we're installing SAP, we're moving to our on distribution away from BMS. And we're going to hold more of that inventory essentially as opposed to our customers. As it turned out, the actual decline in the quarter was in the mid teens in Q4. In that account for a majority of the decrease, if you look at the segment sales for North America and Europe, in Q4 versus Q3, that is the key big driver there.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Terry Bivens from JP Morgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Terry Bivens from JP Morgan.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the guidance for next year which Steve and Pete, I guess you're aware, it's lower than the market was expecting. Now, I do understand the additional cost in the operating expenses due to the compensation, due to the depreciation. But th
componenttext: Just a question on the guidance for next year which Steve and Pete, I guess you're aware, it's lower than the market was expecting. Now, I do understand the additional cost in the operating expenses due to the compensation, due to the depreciation. But the guidance also leads me to believe that this may be a much greater year of investing in the business than perhaps some people expected. Can you help me a little bit with that question, perhaps in terms of what you're planning to spend on marketing, what the various innovation cost may be? I assumed that you would continue along the innovation platform, just along the general questions, just what kind of investment year is this for you guys?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Steve, you're certainly right that we're continuing to invest significantly in the growth of the business. Our investment, our planned investment in advertising, promotions, sales force and R&D will rise approximately in line with our sales growth
componenttext: This is Steve, you're certainly right that we're continuing to invest significantly in the growth of the business. Our investment, our planned investment in advertising, promotions, sales force and R&D will rise approximately in line with our sales growth. We're making important investments in a number of new geographies. I mentioned, our joint venture in the Middle East, we've also had this talk many times about the geographic expansion in China and about the investments we're making in India, Brazil and Russia. So all of those businesses show very exciting long-term potential. But we're clearly in an investment mode for the next few years.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The other point I would make, Terry too, is we've been talking to about the shared service overlap cost. We started out the year expecting them to be $25 million. Last quarter talked about the $20 million and it came in at $18 million. The total cost has
componenttext: The other point I would make, Terry too, is we've been talking to about the shared service overlap cost. We started out the year expecting them to be $25 million. Last quarter talked about the $20 million and it came in at $18 million. The total cost has not changed but there has been a shift to more of that spending coming through in 2011. So as I say, that could be up as much as $6 million in the new year and that's another factor I look.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Katzman from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Katzman from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess my question kind of following up on Terry's, you mentioned a bit on the pricing front, but I think historically when we've talked about the outlook for pricing you've been a bit more cautious than you've seem to have indicated today. Given the wea
componenttext: I guess my question kind of following up on Terry's, you mentioned a bit on the pricing front, but I think historically when we've talked about the outlook for pricing you've been a bit more cautious than you've seem to have indicated today. Given the weakness, I guess, in the U.S. market and the fact that the industry or the category has raised prices pretty aggressively. So, I'm just kind of wondering is there a bit of conservatism in terms of how much pricing you really expected versus that inflation rate, and is that the cause in part due for the margins to kind of be flat in your '11 guidance?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think that isn't what we tried to communicate. Within the sales guidance that we've given you, I indicated that, that would be weighted towards volume. The mix between volume and price as in 2010 is going to be 2/3 towards volume, 1/3 towards price, som
componenttext: I think that isn't what we tried to communicate. Within the sales guidance that we've given you, I indicated that, that would be weighted towards volume. The mix between volume and price as in 2010 is going to be 2/3 towards volume, 1/3 towards price, something of that nature. We're not planning significant price increases. We continue to look at multiple factors market by market to determine our pricing strategies. And the gross margins, we're able to guide you towards flat gross margins principally as a result of our best-in-class productivity programs.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of David Driscoll from Citi.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of David Driscoll from Citi.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Want to move my questions over to North America/Europe segment, really specifically the United States. And hear your most updated comments on the effect of the recall. Honestly, when I looked at the segment sales, I think you've explained that the segment
componenttext: Want to move my questions over to North America/Europe segment, really specifically the United States. And hear your most updated comments on the effect of the recall. Honestly, when I looked at the segment sales, I think you've explained that the segment itself came in below our expectations. And I think the answer to what you're saying was Europe is the area of the weakness. In the United States, do you expect --  well, first of, can you quantify what you think the benefit was of the recall? And the second point on that same topic is, do you think you can hold on to those sales? And if I could just add one further point to put all of the pieces of the question in play, what did Abbott do during the quarter in order to retain customers? I think it was all about lowering pricing on their ready-to-drink product, and I want to know what kind of effect their pricing strategy has on Mead?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: David, let me take first part of the question and then I'll turn it over to Steve. With regard to the impact in the U.S. and market share, we believe if you look at Nielsen data, that you all can have access to, it looks like we've picked up about 2.5 poi
componenttext: David, let me take first part of the question and then I'll turn it over to Steve. With regard to the impact in the U.S. and market share, we believe if you look at Nielsen data, that you all can have access to, it looks like we've picked up about 2.5 points of market share in the fourth quarter relative to the third quarter. Now, we can't separate out how much of that is coming from the recall, how much of that is coming from our product innovation. Both the right work, and as you recall, in the third quarter we mentioned we were seeing share gains prior to the recall. But if you look at the market on a retail basis, it's roughly $2.5 billion, 2.5% of that would imply something on the order of $60 million annually on the quarterly basis about $15 million. So that's the impact that market share as we would see at retail in the fourth quarter.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: As we indicated on the last call, Abbott's principal actions were to drive consumers both towards the smaller pack sizes of their Similac powder product, which as you know, it falls from stores from a different manufacturing plant and we're not affected a
componenttext: As we indicated on the last call, Abbott's principal actions were to drive consumers both towards the smaller pack sizes of their Similac powder product, which as you know, it falls from stores from a different manufacturing plant and we're not affected and towards their liquid products. And they did a very good job of that. The pricing action that they took, you're absolutely right, it was on their liquid products. So they dropped the price of liquid such that an equivalent feeding would cost what it would have done with had powders have been fully available and we followed that action to make sure that our liquids were competitive. We are, as they are now, fully back in the market, we are not seeing any unanticipated or extraordinary pricing actions that clearly seeking to rebuild the equity of the business where it's been impacted. And we're very confident in the program that we have in place and the innovations that we introduced towards the back end of 2010. We are seeing, as you are, I'm sure from your Nielsen data, an improvement in our market share of between 2% and 3% in the fourth quarter and we expect to be able to hold an improved market share through 2011.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Ramney from D. A. Davidson.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Shifting to the market that really drives it, China, it's easy for us to recognize the details of the U.S. but the Chinese market is really the story. And I really don't have a good sense of the competitive landscape and what's happening there, we really
componenttext: Shifting to the market that really drives it, China, it's easy for us to recognize the details of the U.S. but the Chinese market is really the story. And I really don't have a good sense of the competitive landscape and what's happening there, we really do understand the march to greater penetration of cities, but would you mind providing a little more detail on competitive activity there, and how you're faring against other major competitors?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: We grew share significantly in China through 2010, not only as a consequence of our step change program but more importantly, as a consequence of growing penetration and consumption in our core of cities. Around three quarters of the growth that we record
componenttext: We grew share significantly in China through 2010, not only as a consequence of our step change program but more importantly, as a consequence of growing penetration and consumption in our core of cities. Around three quarters of the growth that we recorded last year came from the core cities that we're established in and only a quarter from the improved presence in step changed cities. We don't, as you know, talk about market share data explicitly on a country basis, but I can tell you that we are the number one by value in China, currently. If you combine it with Hong Kong, the number one status is underlined and overall we would say 50% of our annual growth came from a market share improvement for the year and pass as much as 75% of our fourth quarter growth for market share. So we think tremendous momentum that gives great confidence for the future.

componenttext: I'll ask a question on China as well, you talked about entering 50 new cities this year, and I think if I write down correctly, the number that you're already incoming into '11 is 183. If you could give us some granularity on number of percentage of cities that as of the end of last year, as of the end of 2010, you're fully into -- presumably you're not entering all 50 cities, you're all entering cities into '11, on Jan 1, I'm just trying to get a sense of what you are carrying over into 2011 that's not fully integrated from 2010? Or even, I don't know if you go back to as far 2009, it's a marriage, but if that makes sense can you help me out there?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The number was 193, Vincent, at year-end. We have a very disciplined approach to this program and we do make sure that before we move on to a new city that we are fully established and meeting or exceeding very precise and demanding metrics of performance
componenttext: The number was 193, Vincent, at year-end. We have a very disciplined approach to this program and we do make sure that before we move on to a new city that we are fully established and meeting or exceeding very precise and demanding metrics of performance. Because the last thing we want to do is spread our resources too thinly and fail to execute with excellence, though that expansion will be somewhat continuous, it'll be back-end weighted in 2011. I don't expect a year from now to be saying anything very different from what I'm saying now. Three quarters or more of our growth will come from cities in which we are fully established and a quarter or a little less from new cities. In fact, we discussed our China business yesterday with our Board of Directors and without giving too much away, I can say that there are many other ways with step change in the pipeline, and although there aren't any more Beijing, Shanghais and Chengdus to come along, we're still talking about very substantial cities that will allow us to increase penetration and presence for many years to come.

componenttext: Was hoping to give one for Pete here. Can you talk a little bit more about how we're thinking of the cash balance, looking into 2011 and your incremental cash flow? I know CapEx is stepping down a bit this year, are you guys looking to maybe build on your white space expansion, the Russias, the Indies, Brazil, the world, maybe some tack on acquisitions or we start to see more cash back to shareholders this year, can you just bring that up for us a bit?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's very difficult as you might imagine sitting back and saying when any particular deal or transaction might occur, but I think we are certainly are considering M&A as one avenue for growth for the company. We got great returns from organic growth
componenttext: Yes. It's very difficult as you might imagine sitting back and saying when any particular deal or transaction might occur, but I think we are certainly are considering M&A as one avenue for growth for the company. We got great returns from organic growth but that is something that we can flush out and we'll continue to put some emphasis on them in new year. In terms of our cash flow overall, probably it's still very strong, we still have high capital spending in 2011. The other thing I would point out to is we have, we've said in terms of our shared repurchase program where we have $300 million of authorized by the board, that the purpose of that program is to help offset dilution that may come from equity works from employees, and as we've discussed, those have not had a big impact if you look over the last year, but they could have a bigger impact as we move through the new year and that's something that we'll be considering as well.

componenttextpreview: You talked a lot about these PNIs that you're bidding out and they're in Mexico and Guangzhou, maybe it wasn't Mexico, but also adding to bill, how do you balance off having like just one pilot plant, imagine a pilot plant having one in Indiana, versus bu
componenttext: You talked a lot about these PNIs that you're bidding out and they're in Mexico and Guangzhou, maybe it wasn't Mexico, but also adding to bill, how do you balance off having like just one pilot plant, imagine a pilot plant having one in Indiana, versus building them in the countries where you're operating. How does being closer to the local market help your R&D efforts and I guess satisfy with the local needs?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just to clarify, only in Evansville, Indiana, do we have a scalable pilot plant that I referred to that allows us to research and develop manufacturing factory processes without shutting down our manufacturing facility. Our model is, in simple terms, cent
componenttext: Just to clarify, only in Evansville, Indiana, do we have a scalable pilot plant that I referred to that allows us to research and develop manufacturing factory processes without shutting down our manufacturing facility. Our model is, in simple terms, centralized research and discovery, de-centralize product development. The product development, we believe, happens best closest to its consumer, remember a lot of our business in Asia, Latin-America was in the children nutritional area where taste and offerings differ significantly. We also believe it drives speed, we also believe there's a benefit in being closer to the regulators  in the regions of in market to accelerate the pace and effectiveness of our innovation. So we don't plan to build anymore in the foreseeable future, our network of consist of these three Pediatric Nutrition Institutes and a centralized research functions.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I always think of Nestlé as having a dominant business in Latin America and I think Mead is kind of a second or third tier player to do you foresee more market share gains in those markets? And how do you compete against a company like that, that just se
componenttext: I always think of Nestlé as having a dominant business in Latin America and I think Mead is kind of a second or third tier player to do you foresee more market share gains in those markets? And how do you compete against a company like that, that just seems to have the dominant share?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I won't be defensive about your comment about your comment calling it second or third tier. We're truly excited about the current growth performance of our Latin American businesses where, I think every market last year in local currency grew in strong do
componenttext: I won't be defensive about your comment about your comment calling it second or third tier. We're truly excited about the current growth performance of our Latin American businesses where, I think every market last year in local currency grew in strong double-digits. We have very strong market shares in a number of areas in a number of countries, but most exciting is the fact that the category is growing extremely strongly. Consumers, healthcare professionals are more aware of the importance of early life nutrition,  fundamentally favor where economics and demographics. We're investing very heavily in those businesses and infrastructure demand creation, we're putting particular emphasis on Brazil, and in fact, Brazil works on a percentage basis, our fastest growing business in 2010. And yes, you're right, Nestlé has been in the region for a long time, they have a very large presence, but this is a growth category, just because it was and is in China. If you went back far enough, Nestlé would've been the dominant player in China and that isn't the case today. We believe that with better offerings, better science, our proven business model, we can be extremely successful for many -- over a long period of time.

componenttext: It's been running relatively consistently as you mentioned, roughly $12 million a quarter, and we do expect an increase in the low to mid-50s. We did unwind that $200 million swap. Which proved, by the way, to be quite effective for us, it had $20 million in value, $20 million in cash roughly that we brought in. And accounting basically dictates that, that gain has amortization over the remaining life of the dud. So you don't see as much of an impact as you would by -- it'll still be there but it's going to be showing up over time. I would think that it should be reasonably consistent quarter-by-quarter throughout the year at this point.

componenttext: It's low to  mid-50s, if you may recall, we actually have six rate notes outstanding, so the only reason we would be hurt by higher rates is because of the swap and we unwound one of them. We still have one out, but it's probably more of the swap unwind that has a bigger impact.
