componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Mead Johnson Nutrition Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Derek, and I'll be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to Kathryn Chieger, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please proceed, Kathryn.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to Mead Johnson's Fourth Quarter Conference Call, which happens to be my 125th and last quarterly earnings announcement. As many of you know, I will be retiring next week, and I want to say how much I've enjoyed sharin
componenttext: Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to Mead Johnson's Fourth Quarter Conference Call, which happens to be my 125th and last quarterly earnings announcement. As many of you know, I will be retiring next week, and I want to say how much I've enjoyed sharing the Mead Johnson story with all of you these past two years. Let now turn the call over to my friend, colleague and successor, Kathy MacDonald, who will have the pleasure of hosting her first earnings call. Kathy?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathryn. One of my early learnings is to be respectful of investors' time. So, I'll turn to the business at hand. With me today are Steve Golsby, our CEO; and Pete Leemputte, our CFO.Before we get started, let me remind everyone that our comm
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathryn. One of my early learnings is to be respectful of investors' time. So, I'll turn to the business at hand. With me today are Steve Golsby, our CEO; and Pete Leemputte, our CFO.
Before we get started, let me remind everyone that our comments will include forward-looking statements about our future results, including statements about our financial prospects and projections, new product launches and market conditions that constitute forward-looking statements for purposes of the Safe Harbor provision under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Keep in mind that our actual results may differ materially from expectations as of today due to various factors, including those listed in our annual report on Form 10-K for 2009, quarterly reports for Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K and registration statements, in each case, as filed with or furnished to the Securities and Exchange Commission, and our earnings release issued this morning, all of which are available upon request or on our website at meadjohnson.com.
In addition, any forward-looking statements represent our estimates only as of today and should not be relied on as representing our estimates as of any subsequent date. While we may elect to update forward-looking statements at some point in the future, we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so even if our estimates change. Given that we are in the midst of the earnings reporting season, we will keep our call to 45 minutes. 
That said, I will turn the call over to Steve.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathy, and good morning, everyone. As you read in our press release, we concluded 2010 on a very strong note and delivered another year of record sales and earnings. Non-GAAP earnings of $0.57 per share in the fourth quarter were up 19% from 20
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathy, and good morning, everyone. As you read in our press release, we concluded 2010 on a very strong note and delivered another year of record sales and earnings. Non-GAAP earnings of $0.57 per share in the fourth quarter were up 19% from 2009, bringing our full year EPS to $2.42 per share up 9% from the prior year. We accomplished many important goals in 2010, the most notable of which include over 9% constant dollar sales growth, the highest level seen in the last five years. Most encouragingly, it was 5% volume growth that drove the global sales increase. The increase was led by our Asia/Latin America segment which posted 16% growth excluding foreign exchange. We invested heavily behind advertising and promotion, and in sales force expansion in key gross markets, which led to solid market share gains across the American markets of Asia and Latin America. 
Our U.S. business grew despite continued declines in both births and formula consumption, fueled by successful new product launches including our patented Dual Prebiotics' unique packaging system and a newborn product formulated for the first three months of life.
In June, we launched our first joint venture as a public company with Almarai, the leading regional food and dairy producer serving markets in the Middle East. Sales into the market started in the fourth quarter.  Although we are still in an investment mode with this JV, this demonstrates our commitment of fueling long-term growth and to expanding Mead Johnson's global presence. 
Sales outside the U.S. came to represent 68% of the company total, up from 65% in 2009 and 62% in 2008. We opened a new Pediatric Nutrition Institute or PNI in Evansville, Indiana, that gives us the capability of scaling up new manufacturing processes without disrupting our operating plans. We also broke ground on a new PNI in Guangzhou, China, which is set to open late this year and serve as a base for product development in this critical market. 
We set new productivity records that helped to mitigate the impact of higher dairy and commodity costs on our gross margins. We set our earnings record while absorbing a $24 million hit from the January 2010 devaluation of the Venezuelan bolivar, along with a $11 million in incremental non-cash pension expense and $18 million in shared service cost overlap. And as a result of our November 2009 debt refinancing, interest expense was nearly cut in half, and we drove further reductions in our effective tax rate from 30% in 2009 to under 29% in 2010, both contributing strongly to our earnings improvement.
Finally, we made significant progress in building our stand-alone infrastructure, establishing critical capabilities necessary for us to operate independently. Following significant effort by a large number of our associates around the world, we completed the design of our global SAP technology platform during 2010 and went live with the new system in North America during the fourth quarter.
Let's now turn our focus to our regional segments. The impressive growth in Asia and Latin America was led by China and Hong Kong, which together reported sales of $745 million in 2010 and now account for 24% of our global revenues. By the end of 2010, we were fully resourced in 193 cities in China. In 2011, we expect to expand our China geographic footprint into an additional 50 cities through our disciplined step change program. But our Asia/Latin America growth goes beyond just China. We saw strong gains in many markets, including Malaysia and Singapore, as well as in key Latin America markets such as Mexico, Brazil, Colombia and Peru. 
Earlier this month I traveled to Mexico City, where I had the pleasure of opening our new Latin American regional headquarters office, as well as our new Latin America Pediatric Nutrition Institute. This is our third PNI research facility. Our important investment in Latin America will help accelerate our growth and allow us to strengthen innovation and product development for infants and children in the region. 
Sales in the United States increased 5% in the fourth quarter, partially offset by a decline in Europe. I'll talk about our U.S. business in more detail shortly, but let me the first highlight some of the factors that influenced sales in Europe, which account for about 4% of our global business. 
The decline in Europe is largely attributable to the timing of shipments in certain markets. However, we are seeing some evidence of a drop in the birthrate in key markets like Spain that are particularly important to us. Further, there is a shift to the lower-price food store channel away from pharmacies, where our infant formula Nutramigen and other specialty products are sold. 
Turning back to the U.S., we're pleased with the 5% sales growth in the fourth quarter. That's solid progress compared to the 3% real growth we delivered in the third quarter, particularly in light of the continued drop in the overall U.S. market. The CDC recently released new information that indicates that U.S. births were down 4% in the first half of 2010 relative to the first half of 2009. That's an acceleration from the 2.6% drop seen in 2009. WIC infant participation data is more current and is now available through October of 2010. The data shows that births are still declining with lower WIC infant participation in the third and early fourth quarters.
Lower consumption from extended breast-feeding or earlier transition to cow's milk is also being seen. We continue to believe that the U.S. birthrate will ultimately rebound. There are signs of an improving economy that should ultimately lead to higher births. But continued high unemployment in the U.S., as well as the natural lag between planning a pregnancy and the birth, would suggest that births will decline in 2011 and that we won't see any recovery until 2012 at the earliest. 
The contraction in the U.S. market has masked the continued gain in our market share during the fourth quarter that we started to see following the product and packaging innovations launched in the second and third quarters, along with a spike due to a competitor's product recall in late September. That competitor is now back on shelf, but we currently expect 2011 market share on average to be higher than 2010 and offset a lower number of births and reduced formula consumption.
Let's now turn our attention to our outlook for 2011. We expect to produce another year of sales and earnings growth and are initiating 2011 non-GAAP EPS guidance in the range of $2.55 to $2.65, up from $2.42 per share in 2010.
Key assumptions underlying this non-GAAP estimate  include a sales increase of 7% to 8% excluding foreign exchange. At this early point in the year, we anticipate that the top line growth will be more heavily weighted towards volume than price. 
Finally, you will see us continue to increase investments behind demand generation and new product innovation to fuel future growth.
I'll now turn the call over to Pete to provide you further highlights, and will return to wrap up and take your questions.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to start with our 2010 financial results, provide some color on cash flow and also a bit more detail on 2011. Since Steve covered sales growth by segment, let me focus on the cost and margin side of the
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve, and good morning, everyone. I'd like to start with our 2010 financial results, provide some color on cash flow and also a bit more detail on 2011. Since Steve covered sales growth by segment, let me focus on the cost and margin side of the equation. 
First, our gross margin in the fourth quarter was 62.3%, down from the 63.4% reported both in the third quarter and on a full year basis. Higher dairy and commodity costs were at work. We saw spot prices for milk increase during the second quarter, and it takes about six months for these to work through our cost of good sold. Our children's nutrition products, largely sold in Asia and Latin America, contain a higher percentage of dairy by weight, so the impact was more pronounced on this emerging market segment.
In 2011, commodity costs are expected to increase on average in the high single digits. Led by higher dairy prices, other agricultural raw materials and packaging.
Over the last two months, we've seen milk price increases of 5% to as much as 15%. We expect to balance higher commodity costs with strong productivity and some pricing, resulting in gross margins averaging 63.5% in line with 2010.
Operating expenses reached almost 41% of sales in the fourth quarter, the highest level of any quarter this past year and above the 39.4% for the full year. The shared service cost overlap came in at $11 million, more than double the level seen in the third quarter. As a reminder, this overlap represents the temporary duplication of IT, finance and indirect procurement costs as we transition from Bristol-Myers Squibb to IBM. 
We successfully launched SAP in our North American markets and as a result, started to use IBM services to a greater extent during the fourth quarter. We will roll out SAP in our international markets throughout 2011, and charges from IBM will increase as a result. 
On a full year basis, the overlap is expected to grow from $18 million in 2010 to as much as $24 million in 2011, costing us about $0.02 in earnings. We expect to be completely off the Bristol-Myers shared service and IT technology platform by the end of this year.  Our total shared service cost overlap over 2010 and 2011 is expected to fall in the range of $40 million to $42 million, in line with our prior projections.
While operating expenses will be stressed a bit by the increase in shared service costs and a few other items I'll discuss in a minute, we will start to leverage our G&A structure in 2011, while allowing for continued high levels of investment and demand generation.
We expect total operating expenses to center around 39.5% of sales. We will see greater G&A leverage reflected in 2012 and beyond after the completion of our SAP projects.
Let me highlight the overall impact from foreign exchange on our financial results. In 2010, sales increased by 2% for the full year from foreign exchange. The biggest contributor was the weakening of the dollar, most notably in Asia. But this favorable impact was muted by the January 2010 devaluation of the Venezuelan bolivar that took a full point off our sales growth over the course of the year and reduced earnings on a pretax basis by $24 million versus 2009 or $0.08 per share.
Unfortunately, we are facing further headwinds from the bolivar as we enter 2011. In last year's devaluation, the Venezuelan government introduced a dual exchange rate. The first rate, set at 2.6 bolivars per dollar, was for importing essential goods, including much of our product line. The second, set at 4.3 bolivars per dollar, applied to all other goods, as well as profits realized in country.
In December 31st, Venezuela eliminated the dual-rate structure and converged the essentials rate to 4.3 bolivars per dollar. We will see $0.02 of reduced earnings in 2011 relative to 2010 just from this action alone.
Please note that under current market rates, foreign exchange should add about a point and a half to top line growth in 2011.  After the bolivar exchange rate unification, the bottom line impact is a $0.01 or $0.02 of additional earnings.
As Steve mentioned earlier, lower interest expense and a reduced tax rate contributed to earnings growth in 2010. We refinanced our debt in late 2009 and also swapped $700 million of our $1.5 billion in fixed rate notes with floating interest rates. These swaps allowed us to benefit from the low interest rate environment in 2010. When rates started to rise, we took advantage of the appreciated value of the swaps and unwound $200 million in the fourth quarter.
Interest expense should increase from $49 million into the low to mid-$50 million range, depending on whether we unwind the $500 million and remaining fixed to floating interest rate swaps.
Turning to our balance sheet. We ended the year with $596 million in cash, up $35 million from December of 2009. That's after retiring $120 million in debt outstanding against our revolving credit facility in the first quarter, $50 million in contributions to our frozen defined benefit pension plan in the U.S., a dividend increase of 12.5% and $172 million in cash used for capital expenditures, up 80% versus 2009. Investments in our IT technology platform and new packaging lines were the key drivers of the increase. 
Note that on an accrued basis, reflecting actual work performed during the year, capital spending was $143 million, consistent with our $150 million guidance. Accrued capital expenditures for 2011 are currently expected to be about $125 million. Capital spending necessary for our SAP build-out will continue through the year. 
Importantly, there are two non-cash expenses that will reduce earnings per share by a total of $0.09 in 2011 relative to 2010. First, depreciation and amortization expense totaled $65 million in 2010. We expect that to grow to $75 million, largely as a result of our capital investments in IT. A majority of the $10 million G&A increase, which equates to about $0.04 per share, will be seen in operating expenses, as our new IT systems support many business processes like sales managements, order to cash, accounting and indirect procurement.
Secondly, non-cash compensation expense for performance-based equity awards will increase from $20 million to about $35 million, equivalent to another $0.05 in earnings per share. The majority of our annual equity awards are in the form of options and performance shares, with the expense recognized over their three-year vesting period.
As each year has passed since our 2009 IPO, we've recognized the expense from an additional award, though the buildup to three full years of equity awards from 2009, 2010, and 2011 will be reflected in stock-based compensation expense for the first time. Our higher stock price is also a factor. Note that we should not see increases in equity expense of this magnitude in 2012 and beyond with our current three-year equity award cycle.
We made solid progress in 2010 managing controllable working capital, which we define as trade receivables, inventory and accounts payable. Given our high growth rates, we measure ourselves on a percentage of sales basis. We reduced average working capital to 8.7% of sales in 2010 from 12.4% in 2009 and almost 15% in 2008.
These strong results were delivered as inventory and accounts payable management received strong focus and helped us achieve performance significantly better than the 11.4% average seen by our peers.
Let me wrap up my prepared remarks by pulling together the details on our initial 2011 non-GAAP earnings guidance of $2.55 to $2.65 per share. This is based on constant dollar sales growth of 7% to 8% with mid-teen growth in Asia, Latin America and low single-digit growth in North America, Europe. Foreign exchange would add another 1.5% at today's rates. We are currently assuming gross margins to center around 63.5% in line with 2010. 
Operating expenses, measured as a percent of sales should be relatively flat at about 39.5% after absorbing $0.09 in added non-cash expense for G&A along with equity-based compensation. 
And finally, the effective tax rate for 2011 is expected to fall between 28% and 29%. All in all, we've targeted another strong year of performance. Before I turn the call back to Steve, let me offer my thanks to Kathryn for her dedicated service to Mead Johnson. She's done a great job establishing and leading our Investor Relations function over the past two years.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pete. First, I also want to personally thank Kathryn for her excellent work over the last couple of years, and wish her well in her retirement. I'd like to conclude by acknowledging the efforts of all our Mead Johnson colleagues around the gl
componenttext:
Thank you, Pete. First, I also want to personally thank Kathryn for her excellent work over the last couple of years, and wish her well in her retirement. 
I'd like to conclude by acknowledging the efforts of all our Mead Johnson colleagues around the globe, who delivered such strong performance in 2010. I know that they share my commitment to our mission, our strategy and to ensuring that we continue to drive sustainable, profitable growth in 2011. 
We'll now be pleased to take your questions. To give everyone an opportunity to participate, we request that you ask just one question and, if necessary, a follow-up, and then we will pass it along to the next person in the queue. 
Operator, please open the line for questions.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  And the first question comes from the line of Ed Aaron with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  And the first question comes from the line of Ed Aaron with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow up a little bit on Europe. How are you planning for that business going forward? Because there seems to have been a somewhat meaningful change in -- behavioral change among consumers that developed in the quarter? And then could you jus
componenttext: I wanted to follow up a little bit on Europe. How are you planning for that business going forward? Because there seems to have been a somewhat meaningful change in -- behavioral change among consumers that developed in the quarter? And then could you just give us a sense of -- just with the inventory, I know you had talked about taking $10 million out there in the quarter. How did that shake out? And then what are the expectations for destocking in Europe in 2011? And does the change in the market dynamic affect the amount that you're looking to take out of inventory ahead of the transition of your distribution?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ed, I'll take the first part of the question, and then Pete can cover your question on inventories. As I mentioned in the script, that Europe accounts for about 4% of our business. The business has grown over time but represents a lower proportion of sale
componenttext: Ed, I'll take the first part of the question, and then Pete can cover your question on inventories. As I mentioned in the script, that Europe accounts for about 4% of our business. The business has grown over time but represents a lower proportion of sales as a consequence of the rapid growth in our Asia/Latin American businesses. We have a very strong position in the allergy management sector, particularly with our Nutramigen brand. And we have a growing presence in a few selected markets in the PREMIUM, Routine, and Per Formula segments. Nevertheless, the region is seeing many of the same fundamental changes that we see in North America, with lower birth and lower consumption. It's also a very competitive region, and as you stated, Ed, there is something of a shift, due to the challenging economy from the pharmacies to the food channel, where lower-price offerings are available. We will continue to evolve our strategy and our business model. In 2011, we riveted on the transformation to the new SAP technology platform to the new distributor program model.  And to ensuring that we continue to grow the core parts of our business in selected areas. But don't expect it to increase as a proportion of our business in the foreseeable future. Pete, do you want to take the inventory point?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. Ed, you're completely correct. We had indicated last quarter that we were expecting about a $10 million or $11 million inventory adjustment coming in the fourth quarter. This is different than what we saw in the prior year.  We're moving, we're inst
componenttext: Sure. Ed, you're completely correct. We had indicated last quarter that we were expecting about a $10 million or $11 million inventory adjustment coming in the fourth quarter. This is different than what we saw in the prior year.  We're moving, we're installing SAP, we're moving to our own distribution away from BMS. And we're going to hold more of that inventory centrally as opposed to our customers. As it turned out, the actual decline in the quarter was in the mid teens in Q4. And that accounts for a majority of the decrease. If you look at the segment sales for North America and Europe in Q4 versus Q3, that is the key big driver there.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Terry Bivens from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Terry Bivens from JPMorgan.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the guidance for next year, which Steve and Pete, I guess you're aware it's lower than the market was expecting. Now I do understand the additional costs in the operating expenses due to the compensation, due to the depreciation. But th
componenttext: Just a question on the guidance for next year, which Steve and Pete, I guess you're aware it's lower than the market was expecting. Now I do understand the additional costs in the operating expenses due to the compensation, due to the depreciation. But the guidance also leads me to believe that this may be a much greater year of investing in the business than perhaps some people expected. Can you help me a little bit with that question, perhaps in terms of what you're planning to spend on marketing, what the various innovation costs may be? I assume that you would continue along the innovation platform.  Just along the general questions of just what kind of investment year is this for you guys.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Terry, you're certainly right that we are continuing to invest significantly in the growth of the business. Our investment, our planned investment in advertising, promotions, sales force and R&D will rise approximately in line with our sales growth. We're
componenttext: Terry, you're certainly right that we are continuing to invest significantly in the growth of the business. Our investment, our planned investment in advertising, promotions, sales force and R&D will rise approximately in line with our sales growth. We're making important investments in a number of new geographies. I mentioned our joint venture in the Middle East.  You've also heard us talk many times about the geographic expansion in China and about the investments we're making in India, Brazil and Russia. So all of those businesses show very exciting long-term potential. But we're clearly in an investment mode for the next few years.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The other point I would make, Terry, too, is we've been talking to you about the shared service overlap costs. We started out the year expecting them to be $25 million. Last quarter, I talked about $20 million, and it came in at $18 million. The total cos
componenttext: The other point I would make, Terry, too, is we've been talking to you about the shared service overlap costs. We started out the year expecting them to be $25 million. Last quarter, I talked about $20 million, and it came in at $18 million. The total cost has not changed, but there has been a shift to more of that spending coming through in 2011. So as I say, that could be up as much as $6 million in the new year, and that's another factor at work.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Katzman from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Katzman from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess my question, kind of following up on Terry's, you mentioned a bit on the pricing front, but I think historically when we've talked about the outlook for pricing you've been a bit more cautious than you've seem to have indicated today, given the we
componenttext: I guess my question, kind of following up on Terry's, you mentioned a bit on the pricing front, but I think historically when we've talked about the outlook for pricing you've been a bit more cautious than you've seem to have indicated today, given the weakness, I guess, in the U.S. market and the fact that the industry or the category has raised prices pretty aggressively. So I'm just kind of wondering is there a bit of conservatism in terms of how much pricing you really expected versus that inflation rate, and is that the cause in part due for the margins to kind of be flat in your '11 guidance?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think that isn't what we tried to communicate. Within the sales guidance that we've given you, I indicated that, that would be weighted towards volume. The mix between volume and price as in 2010 is going to be 2/3 towards volume, 1/3 towards price, som
componenttext: I think that isn't what we tried to communicate. Within the sales guidance that we've given you, I indicated that, that would be weighted towards volume. The mix between volume and price as in 2010 is going to be 2/3 towards volume, 1/3 towards price, something of that nature. We're not planning significant price increases. We continue to look at multiple factors market-by-market to determine our pricing strategies. And the gross margins, we're able to guide you towards flat gross margins principally as a result of our best-in-class productivity programs.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of David Driscoll from Citi.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of David Driscoll from Citi.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Want to move my questions over to North America/Europe segment, really specifically the United States and hear your most updated comments on the effect of the recall. And honestly, when I looked at the segment sales, I think you've explained that the segm
componenttext: Want to move my questions over to North America/Europe segment, really specifically the United States and hear your most updated comments on the effect of the recall. And honestly, when I looked at the segment sales, I think you've explained that the segment itself came in below our expectations. And I think the answer, what you were saying was Europe was the area of the weakness. In the United States, do you expect -- well, first of, can you quantify what you think the benefit was of the recall? And the second point on that same topic is, do you think you can hold on to those sales? And if I could just add one further point to put all of the pieces of the question in play, what did Abbott do during the quarter in order to retain customers? I think it was all about lowering pricing on their ready-to-drink product, and I want to know what kind of effect their pricing strategy has on Mead?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, David. Let me take first part of the question and then I'll turn it over to Steve. With regard to the impact in the U.S. on market share, we believe if you look at Nielsen data, that you all can have access to, it looks like we picked up about 2.5 p
componenttext: Sure, David. Let me take first part of the question and then I'll turn it over to Steve. With regard to the impact in the U.S. on market share, we believe if you look at Nielsen data, that you all can have access to, it looks like we picked up about 2.5 points of market share in the fourth quarter relative to the third quarter. Now we can't separate out how much of that is coming from the recall, how much of that is coming from our product innovation. Both are at work, and as you recall, in the third quarter we mentioned we were seeing share gains prior to their recall. But if you look at the market on a retail basis, it's roughly $2.5 billion, 2.5% of that would imply something on the order of $60 million annually, or on the quarterly basis, about $15 million. So that's the impact of market share as we would see at retail in the fourth quarter.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: As we indicated on the last call, Abbott's principal actions were to drive consumers both towards the smaller pack sizes of their Similac powder product, which, as you know, it's sourced from a different manufacturing plant and we're not affected, and tow
componenttext: As we indicated on the last call, Abbott's principal actions were to drive consumers both towards the smaller pack sizes of their Similac powder product, which, as you know, it's sourced from a different manufacturing plant and we're not affected, and towards their liquid products. And they did a very good job of that. The pricing action that they took, you're absolutely right, was on their liquid products. So they dropped the price of liquids such that an equivalent feeding would cost what it would have done with -- had powders have been fully available. And we followed that action to make sure that our liquids were competitive. We are, as they are now, fully back in the market. We are not seeing any unanticipated or extraordinary pricing actions. They're clearly seeking to rebuild the equity of the business where it's been impacted. And we're very confident in the programs that we have in place and the innovations that we introduced towards the back end of 2010. We are seeing, as you are, I'm sure from your Nielsen data, an improvement in our market share of between 2% and 3% in the fourth quarter, and we expect to be able to hold and improve market share through 2011.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Ramey from D.A. Davidson.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tim Ramey from D.A. Davidson.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: So shifting to the market that really drives it, China, it's easy for us to agonize about details in the U.S., but the Chinese market is really the story. And i guess I really don't have a good sense of the competitive landscape and what's happening there
componenttext: So shifting to the market that really drives it, China, it's easy for us to agonize about details in the U.S., but the Chinese market is really the story. And i guess I really don't have a good sense of the competitive landscape and what's happening there. We really do understand the march to greater penetration of cities, but would you mind providing a little more detail on competitive activity there and how you're faring against other major operators?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: We grew share significantly in China through 2010, not only as a consequence of our step change program but more importantly, as a consequence of growing penetration and consumption in our core cities. Around 3/4 of the growth that we recorded last year c
componenttext: We grew share significantly in China through 2010, not only as a consequence of our step change program but more importantly, as a consequence of growing penetration and consumption in our core cities. Around 3/4 of the growth that we recorded last year came from the core cities that we're established in and only a quarter from the improved presence in the step change cities. We don't, as you know, talk about market share data explicitly on a country basis, but I can tell you that we are the number one by value in China, currently. If you combine it with Hong Kong, that number one status is underlined, and overall we would say 50% of our annual growth came from a market share improvement for the year and perhaps as much as 75% of our fourth quarter growth from market share. So we're seeing tremendous momentum that gives us great confidence for the future.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Vincent Andrews from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Vincent Andrews from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll ask a question on China as well.  You talked about entering 50 new cities this year, and I think if I wrote it down correctly, the number that you're already in coming into '11 is 183. I just -- if you could give us some granularity on number or perc
componenttext: I'll ask a question on China as well.  You talked about entering 50 new cities this year, and I think if I wrote it down correctly, the number that you're already in coming into '11 is 183. I just -- if you could give us some granularity on number or percentage of cities that as of the end of last year, as of the end of 2010, you were fully into -- because presumably you're not entering all 50 cities -- you didn't enter into all 50 cities in 2011 on Jan. 1, so I'm just trying to get a sense of what are you sort of carrying over into 2011 that's not fully integrated from 2010? Or even, I don't know if you go back as far 2009 in some areas, but just, if that makes sense, can you help me out there?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The number was 193, Vincent, at year end. We have a very disciplined approach to this program, and we do make sure that before we move on to a new city that we are fully established and are meeting or exceeding very precise and demanding metrics of perfor
componenttext: The number was 193, Vincent, at year end. We have a very disciplined approach to this program, and we do make sure that before we move on to a new city that we are fully established and are meeting or exceeding very precise and demanding metrics of performance. Because the last thing we want to do is spread our resources too thinly and fail to execute with excellence.  So that expansion will be somewhat continuous.  It'll be back-end weighted in 2011. I don't expect a year from now to be saying anything very different from what I'm saying now. Three quarters or more of our growth will come from cities in which we are fully established and a quarter or a little less from new cities. In fact, we discussed our China business yesterday with our Board of Directors, and without giving too much away, I can say that there are many other waves of step change in the pipeline, and although there aren't any more Beijings, Shanghais and Chengdus to come along, we're still talking about very substantial cities that will allow us to increase penetration and presence for many years to come.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would also just add, Vincent, that in terms of the timing, as we move through the year, if that's part of your question too, the additional cities that we moved into tended to get to a fully staffed position in the second half of the year probably on av
componenttext: I would also just add, Vincent, that in terms of the timing, as we move through the year, if that's part of your question too, the additional cities that we moved into tended to get to a fully staffed position in the second half of the year probably on average.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: That 193 you consider fully established today, is that correct?
componenttext: That 193 you consider fully established today, is that correct?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: We do, yes.
componenttext: We do, yes.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Andrew Sawyer from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Andrew Sawyer from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to give one for Pete here. Can you talk a little bit more about how we're thinking about the cash balance, looking into 2011 and your incremental cash flow? I know CapEx is stepping down a bit this year? Are you guys looking to maybe build on
componenttext: I was hoping to give one for Pete here. Can you talk a little bit more about how we're thinking about the cash balance, looking into 2011 and your incremental cash flow? I know CapEx is stepping down a bit this year? Are you guys looking to maybe build on your white space expansion to the Russias, the Indias, Brazils of the world, with maybe some tack-on acquisitions? Or are we started seeing more cash back to shareholders this year? Can you just bring that up for us a bit?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's very difficult, as you might imagine, sitting back and saying when any particular deal or transaction might occur, but I think we are -- we certainly are considering M&A as one avenue for growth for the company. And we get great returns from org
componenttext: Yes. It's very difficult, as you might imagine, sitting back and saying when any particular deal or transaction might occur, but I think we are -- we certainly are considering M&A as one avenue for growth for the company. And we get great returns from organic growth, but that is something that we can flesh out and will continue to put some emphasis on in the new year. In terms of our cash flow overall, it's obviously very strong. We still have high capital spending in 2011. The other thing I would point out too is we have -- we've said in terms of our share repurchase program where we have $300 million of, authorized by the board, that the purpose of that program is to help offset dilution that may come from equity awards to employees, and as we've discussed, those have not had a big impact if you look over the last year, but they could have a bigger impact as we move through the new year, and that's something that we'll be considering as well.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm guessing you'll say "no comment," but any chance you guys are taking a look at that small business that's for sale in India?
componenttext: I'm guessing you'll say "no comment," but any chance you guys are taking a look at that small business that's for sale in India?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: We don't speculate or comment on what deals we would or wouldn't be looking at.
componenttext: We don't speculate or comment on what deals we would or wouldn't be looking at.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think you may have missed something on your top line guidance. I think you said mid teens for Asia, Lat-Am? And was it low single digits for the U.S. Europe?
componenttext: I think you may have missed something on your top line guidance. I think you said mid teens for Asia, Lat-Am? And was it low single digits for the U.S. Europe?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, low single digits.
componenttext: Yes, low single digits.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: You talked a lot about these PNIs that you're building out, and they're in Mexico and Guangzhou, maybe it wasn't Mexico, but also Evansville.  How do you balance off having kind of like just one pilot plant, I imagine they're pilot plants, having one in I
componenttext: You talked a lot about these PNIs that you're building out, and they're in Mexico and Guangzhou, maybe it wasn't Mexico, but also Evansville.  How do you balance off having kind of like just one pilot plant, I imagine they're pilot plants, having one in Indiana, versus building them in the countries where you're operating? How does being closer to the local market help your R&D efforts and I guess satisfy with the local needs?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just to clarify, only in Evansville, Indiana, do we have the scalable pilot plant that I referred to that allows us to research and develop manufacturing processes without shutting down our manufacturing facilities. Our model is, in simple terms, centrali
componenttext: Just to clarify, only in Evansville, Indiana, do we have the scalable pilot plant that I referred to that allows us to research and develop manufacturing processes without shutting down our manufacturing facilities. Our model is, in simple terms, centralized research and discovery, decentralized product development. The product development, we believe, happens best closest to the consumer. Remember, a lot of our business in Asia, Latin-America is in the children's nutritional area, where tastes and offerings differ significantly. We also believe it drives speed. We also believe there's a benefit in being closer to the regulators  in the regions and the markets to accelerate the pace and effectiveness of our innovation. So we don't plan to build any more in the foreseeable future.  Our network will consist of these three Pediatric Nutrition Institutes and a centralized research function.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I always think of Nestlé as having a dominant business in Latin America, and I think Mead is kind of a second- or third-tier player.  Do you foresee more market share gains in those markets? And how do you compete against a company like that, that just s
componenttext: I always think of Nestlé as having a dominant business in Latin America, and I think Mead is kind of a second- or third-tier player.  Do you foresee more market share gains in those markets? And how do you compete against a company like that, that just seems to have the dominant share?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I won't be defensive about your comment, calling us second or third tier. We're truly excited about the current growth performance of our Latin American businesses, where I think every market last year in local currency grew in strong double digits. We ha
componenttext: I won't be defensive about your comment, calling us second or third tier. We're truly excited about the current growth performance of our Latin American businesses, where I think every market last year in local currency grew in strong double digits. We have very strong market shares in a number of areas in a number of countries, but most exciting is the fact that the category is growing extremely strongly. Consumers, healthcare professionals are more aware of the importance of early life nutrition,  fundamentally favorable economics and demographics. We're investing very heavily in those businesses, in infrastructure, demand creation. We're putting particular emphasis on Brazil, and in fact, Brazil was on a percentage basis our fastest-growing business in 2010. And yes, you're right, Nestlé has been in the region for a long time. They have a very large presence, but this is a growth category, just as it was and is in China. If you went back far enough, Nestlé would have been the dominant player in China, and that isn't the case today. So we believe that with better offerings, better science, our proven business model, we can be extremely successful for many -- over a long period of time.

componenttextpreview: It's been running relatively consistently as you mentioned, roughly $12 million a quarter, and we do expect an increase into the low to mid-50s. We did unwind that $200 million swap, which proved, by the way, to be quite effective for us.  It had $20 mill
componenttext: It's been running relatively consistently as you mentioned, roughly $12 million a quarter, and we do expect an increase into the low to mid-50s. We did unwind that $200 million swap, which proved, by the way, to be quite effective for us.  It had $20 million in value, $20 million in cash roughly that we brought in. And accounting basically dictates that, that gain has amortized over the remaining life of the debt. So you don't see as much of an impact as you would by -- it'll still be there, but it's going to be showing up over time. I would think that it should be reasonably consistent quarter-by-quarter throughout the year at this point.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Mead Johnson Nutrition First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Kendall, and I'll be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to Ka
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Mead Johnson Nutrition First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Kendall, and I'll be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to Kathy MacDonald, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please proceed, Kathy.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to Mead Johnson's First Quarter Conference Call. With me today are Stephen Golsby, our CEO; and Pete Leemputte, our CFO.Before we get started, let me remind everyone that our comments will include forward-looking sta
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. Welcome to Mead Johnson's First Quarter Conference Call. With me today are Stephen Golsby, our CEO; and Pete Leemputte, our CFO.
Before we get started, let me remind everyone that our comments will include forward-looking statements about our future results, including statements about our financial prospects and projections, new product launches and market conditions that constitute forward-looking statements for purposes of the Safe Harbor provisions under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Keep in mind that our actual results may differ materially from expectations as of today due to various factors, including those listed in our annual report on Form 10-K for 2010, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K and registration statements, in each case, as filed with or furnished to the Securities and Exchange Commission, and our earnings release issued this morning, all of which are available upon request or on our website at www.meadjohnson.com.
In addition, any forward-looking statements represent our estimates only as of today and should not be relied on as representing our estimates as of any subsequent date. While we may elect to update forward-looking statements at some time in the future, we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so even if our estimates change. Given that we are in the midst of the earnings reporting season, we will be respectful of your time and keep our call to 45 minutes. I will now turn the call over to Steve.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathy, and good morning, everyone. Well, 2011 is off to a great start. As you've likely read in our press release, in the first quarter, sales of $900 million grew by 18% or 15% excluding the impact of foreign exchange. This is the highest quar
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathy, and good morning, everyone. Well, 2011 is off to a great start. As you've likely read in our press release, in the first quarter, sales of $900 million grew by 18% or 15% excluding the impact of foreign exchange. This is the highest quarterly growth recorded for many years and is testimony to our strategy. 
Our growth was led by the strength of our business in emerging markets, but also by improved performance in the U.S. In addition, strong gross margins, the timing of demand generation investments and the slightly lower tax rate versus 2010 each contributed to impressive financial results. 
The fundamental drivers in our strategy and operations have not changed, so I'll keep my comments brief and only address key highlights. Sales for the Asia/Latin America markets grew at a rate of 27% or 22% excluding the impact of foreign exchange. This segment now accounts for over 64% of sales, up from 60% in the first quarter of 2010. This exceptional performance was led by China and Hong Kong, where sales grew well in excess of our segment average and where we continue to see gains in market share. 
I recently took several secondary cities in China that we have entered by our systematic step change program. As you may recall, this step change program expands our direct presence into more cities, with a full complement of advertising and promotional support and the addition of medical and trade sales staff. At year end 2010, we had a direct presence in 193 cities and intend to expand into at least another 50 this year. 
I traveled to both the western and eastern regions of China and was struck by the rapid development of world-class infrastructure and by the obvious strength of economic activity. We visited several leading hospitals and visited many retail outlets, including branches of international chains. The category in which Mead Johnson competes is growing very strongly in all of these cities, and our own brands are performing well ahead of expectations. 
While the step change program expands our geographic footprint, we are pleased that 80% of our growth continues to come from cities where we had a full presence in the prior year quarter. 
Our brand equity, science and product quality, geographic footprint expansion and strong execution have all contributed to Mead Johnson achieving market share leadership in China/Hong Kong, and we continue to believe that significant growth will be sustained for many years. 
While China is our largest business outside the U.S., I want to highlight that nearly all of our Latin America markets posted double-digit growth. 
In the North America/Europe segment, both recorded and constant dollar sales grew by 5%. Sales in the U.S. increased at a rate above the segment average but were partially offset by lower sales in Europe, distorted by our transition to a new distribution model. We're very pleased with a strong U.S. performance as it was largely driven by higher market share from product and packaging innovation, as well as a benefit from a competitive product recall last September. 
We've seen encouraging support from consumers, healthcare professionals and the retail trade for our patented newborn infant formula, our Dual Prebiotics plan in the new packaging system comprised of a plastic system comprised of a plastic tab with a retail value box. 
Keep in mind that year-over-year shared comparisons will get tougher in the second half of 2011 since our key competitor is back on shelf, and we will loose the benefit of the parents who switched to Enfamil last fall as their babies age out of the category. 
Additionally, we continue to be pressured by the lower birth rate and reduced consumption in the U.S. The most recent shows that the number of infants participating in the program continues to fall. On a full year basis, our sales in the U.S. are expected to grow slightly as higher market share offsets these downward pressures on the category. 
For the full year, we now anticipate constant dollar global sales growth of around 10% based on our strong performance in the quarter, particularly in emerging markets, with non-GAAP EPS in the range of $2.62 to $2.70 per share. EPS in the remaining quarters of the year will be lower on average than the first quarter, reflecting headwinds from higher dairy costs and increased operating expenses. 
Advertising and promotion spending ran at a low level in the first quarter due to the phasing of key activities so much of the planned increase in operating expense is yet to come. We'll continue to invest in our strong momentum and look for additional growth opportunities in our priority markets. I'll now turn the call over to Pete to provide you further highlights and will return to wrap up and take our questions.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve, and good morning, everyone. Let me add a few more details on our Q1 financial results. The 15% increase in constant dollar sales was comprised of 4% from pricing and volume gains of 11%. As has been the case for many quarters, all of the pr
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve, and good morning, everyone. Let me add a few more details on our Q1 financial results. The 15% increase in constant dollar sales was comprised of 4% from pricing and volume gains of 11%. As has been the case for many quarters, all of the price growth came from our Asia/Latin America segment. 
We took increased pricing in select markets during the quarter and also realized the carryover of inflationary increases taken in other markets during the second half of last year. 
Volume gains of 15% in the Asia/Latin America segment were very broad-based across most markets, while the 5% in North America/Europe was largely driven by the strength of our U.S. business. Note that about 2 points of our Asia/Latin America sales growth was due to snow-related delivery delays in China late last December. That moved sales recognition from the fourth quarter to the current quarter. For the company in total, that was equivalent to just over one point of sales growth or about $0.02 per share in added earnings. 
Keep in mind that sales comparisons are significantly easier in the first half of this year. Over the first 6 months of 2010, we delivered constant dollar sales growth of 5%, jumping to 13% in the second half. As a result, our full year sales growth estimate of around 10% for 2011 is below the 15% delivered in the first quarter. Note that we currently expect about a 1/3-2/3 split between pricing and volume for the full year. 
Turning to foreign exchange, we expect currency fluctuation to add about 2 points to sales growth for the full year. However, we won't see any benefit to our bottom line. In fact, foreign exchange movement adversely affected our bottom line in the first quarter. 
The dollar fell slightly or was flat against most currencies over the last 3 months. In general, a weakening dollar increases sales and earnings. One of the key exceptions is the euro where we have costs which exceed revenues. Our business in Europe is relatively small, and most of the capacity for our Dutch plant is exported to Asia. As a result of the short position, earnings dropped when the dollar weakened against the euro, and that was the scenario we faced in the first quarter as the dollar fell by 6%. This factor, coupled with the devaluation of the Vietnam dong resulted in a balance sheet remeasurement that reduced pretax earnings by over $8 million or $0.03 per share. Note that the impact is evident in other expenses on our income statement.
Gross margins came in at 64.4% for the first quarter, flat with the prior year and up 210 basis points from the fourth quarter. We saw a temporary benefit in our cost of goods sold from lower dairy stock prices in the third quarter of last year. As a reminder, there is a natural lag of about 7 months before stock price fluctuation show up in our product costs, reflecting pricing mechanisms in supply contracts in our normal inventory turns. 
We are facing higher dairy prices in our cost of goods sold for the rest of the year, and that will bring full year gross margins to give or take 63.3%. That's a drop of about 20 basis points versus our prior guidance, which anticipated average 2011 gross margins of 63.5%. 
Over the last 3 months, we have seen global dairy prices continue to increase. They have stabilized a bit in the last month but we will continue to watch commodity costs closely and take our own pricing actions where appropriate. 
Operating expenses were 37.9% from the first quarter, below the 39.5% anticipated for the full year, largely from timing of advertising and promotion spend. A&P can vary significantly quarter-to-quarter based on the timing of product launches or promotional campaigns. A&P stood at 12.4% in Q1, 160 basis points below the 14% expected for the full year. 
As Steve mentioned, we will continue to maintain an A&P and sales force spending as a percentage of sales in line with our higher sales growth. We use this as an opportunity to help fuel additional demand generation investments. This factor, coupled with the FX balance sheet remeasurement spend mentioned earlier will keep full year operating expenses at our January projection of 39.5%. 
Our effective tax rate or ETR, came in at 29.4%, down from 31% from the first quarter of 2010. Please note that we previously expected the full year rate to range from 28% to 29%. We now believe that we'll be at or slightly above 29% as our earnings mix have shifted towards markets that carry higher ETRs. Compared to the midpoint of our prior range, the increased tax rate reduces 2011 earnings by $0.03 per share. 
Pulling all this information together, we now expect 2011 earnings to range between $2.62 to $2.70 per share, up from the $2.55 to $2.65 anticipated 3 months ago. Stronger sales growth in emerging markets is the key driver, partially offset by the impact of higher dairy costs, foreign exchange, higher investments for sustainable growth and a slight increase in our effective tax rate. 
Finally, our cash balance stood at $709 million, up from $596 million in December. That strong performance, given that we repurchased 400,000 shares in the quarter, consuming $24 million of cash. Although the timing and amount of future share repurchases may vary, our program is designed to help reduce the dilutive impact of employee equity awards. When coupled with the 16% increase in our quarterly dividend, we are returning a meaningful portion of our free cash flow to shareholders. For the full year, capital spending and depreciation and amortization expense are expected to be about $125 million and $75 million, respectively. With that, let me now turn the call back to Steve.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pete. We've marked our second year anniversary of being an independent company, and as you can read in our annual report, we are growing stronger every day. I'm happy to announce that we will host an Investor Day on October 13 in Chicago. Kathy
componenttext:
Thank you, Pete. We've marked our second year anniversary of being an independent company, and as you can read in our annual report, we are growing stronger every day. I'm happy to announce that we will host an Investor Day on October 13 in Chicago. Kathy will be sending out further details in the near future. 
In closing, I would like to thank and acknowledge the efforts of all of our Mead Johnson colleagues around the globe who continue to deliver strong performance. We will now be pleased to take your questions. To give everyone an opportunity to participate, we request that you ask just one question and if necessary, a follow-up, and then we will pass it along to the next person in the queue. Operator, please open the line for questions.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Ed Aaron with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Ed Aaron with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I actually wanted to ask a question about emerging markets. Have you seen any cases or do you have any concern about the potential for price controls to perhaps be implemented in any of the markets in which you compete?
componenttext: I actually wanted to ask a question about emerging markets. Have you seen any cases or do you have any concern about the potential for price controls to perhaps be implemented in any of the markets in which you compete?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ed. There are a couple of markets in Asia, namely Thailand and Vietnam, where some price control exists. I think that clearly, your question is likely focused on China and what may happen there. The Chinese government currently is very much foc
componenttext: Thank you, Ed. There are a couple of markets in Asia, namely Thailand and Vietnam, where some price control exists. I think that clearly, your question is likely focused on China and what may happen there. The Chinese government currently is very much focused on quality and food safety but they're also aware of the risk of food inflation, and there are some food categories that they are putting under control or under watch. That does not, at this point in time, include infant formula. We're not immune to these sensitivities, and we have to be watchful as we consider taking further price increases. But there have never been any price controls that have materialized in China, and we don't expect that to be the case in the near future.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great, thank you. And then just one quick follow up, I guess, for Pete. You mentioned the full year operating expense guidance is still up 39.5% of sales, and I understand that you're spending on A&P but I was wondering why we might not see a little bit m
componenttext: Great, thank you. And then just one quick follow up, I guess, for Pete. You mentioned the full year operating expense guidance is still up 39.5% of sales, and I understand that you're spending on A&P but I was wondering why we might not see a little bit more leverage on the MS&A line?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ed. The one other point there, as I mentioned, we had about $8 million in foreign exchange losses, the balance sheet remeasurement related with the Vietnamese dong and more importantly with the weakening of the dollar against the euro, and that's th
componenttext: Sure, Ed. The one other point there, as I mentioned, we had about $8 million in foreign exchange losses, the balance sheet remeasurement related with the Vietnamese dong and more importantly with the weakening of the dollar against the euro, and that's the other key factor driving there.  And I think too, given the strong performance of the company, it's not just A&Pes dollar but also sales force investments and maybe some other marketing investments that we intend to make.

componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow up here on the Asian and Latin American segment in the volume comments. Could you maybe spend a little bit more time to understand, to help us understand the 15% volume growth number? I think you called out 2 points of a shipment differ
componenttext: I wanted to follow up here on the Asian and Latin American segment in the volume comments. Could you maybe spend a little bit more time to understand, to help us understand the 15% volume growth number? I think you called out 2 points of a shipment differential so then that would put perhaps the ongoing run rate or maybe an honest organic rate, if I could say it like, that is 13%. So when I look back over the course of '09 and '10 quarterly data, we just don't see anything this strong, and I'm just trying to understand whether this is a sustainable issue, whether this is one time in nature? Steve, how can you dimensionalize this for us?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll come back to that in a second, Dave. I'll just let Pete explain the numbers and then I'll give a comment.
componenttext: I'll come back to that in a second, Dave. I'll just let Pete explain the numbers and then I'll give a comment.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. That 15% that you referenced for volume for Asia/Latin America is what we reported. We had about 2 points of it. That was due to the fact that there was some heavy snow, particularly in eastern and northern China in late December, and we had a lot o
componenttext: Sure. That 15% that you referenced for volume for Asia/Latin America is what we reported. We had about 2 points of it. That was due to the fact that there was some heavy snow, particularly in eastern and northern China in late December, and we had a lot of goods that have been shipped but had not been yet received and we didn't recognize the sales on that until the first quarter so that's 2 points of it. In addition, David, there was one other factor I would point out. In Venezuela, you may recall in January 1, 2010, the government devalued the currency significantly and put in some new control. And as a result of that dislocation plus the fact that we were transitioning product registrations down there from BMS to Mead Johnson, our sales were abnormally light in the first quarter of last year. That added about another 4 points to sales growth in the quarter. So absent those, it's probably closer to '12. The other thing I would point out is keep in mind, if you look at the quarterly sales from 2010, we did see that very significant increase, and this was true not only in the United States but also in North America/Europe but also in Asia/Latin America. So the comparisons are just a bit easier this quarter than I think that happened. That doesn't allow the fact that we had very, very good performance in the year in terms of volume growth in Asia/Latin America but just an easier comparison as well.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And David, I would just say a couple of things.  We're clearly not growing market share in every country in which we operate. This is a highly competitive industry, and we face challenges just like any other business. But overall, from 11 country aggregat
componenttext: And David, I would just say a couple of things.  We're clearly not growing market share in every country in which we operate. This is a highly competitive industry, and we face challenges just like any other business. But overall, from 11 country aggregate, we've outpaced the category growth every quarter since November 2008. A lot of the volume growth clearly comes from China and Hong Kong, and it would be difficult to say that we're going to continue to see category growth and market share gains of this magnitude consistently, although that will clearly be our aim. But we are also seeing very strong volume growth right across Latin America and in a number of other Asian markets. So we're very confident in the revised guidelines, the growth guidance that we issue to you this morning.

componenttext: Just 2 quick questions on China. The effects, if any, of the Japanese nuclear accident, has that helped your consumption in China? And the other thing, Steve, there has been some talk that the Chinese government might allow a one-time upward reevaluation on the RMB [renminbi]. I'd like to get your take on that, if I might.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first one, Terry. Firstly, let me add to comments to many CEOs have made and to those affected by the disaster in Japan. We do not have operations there and don't intend to have. We are seeing some small benefit from this disaster. As a cons
componenttext: I'll take the first one, Terry. Firstly, let me add to comments to many CEOs have made and to those affected by the disaster in Japan. We do not have operations there and don't intend to have. We are seeing some small benefit from this disaster. As a consequence of the fact that the Japanese manufacturers have infant formula and growing-up milks had a market position in Hong Kong and in parts of China. And clearly, they are facing some supply interruptions and facing some erosion of consumer confidence, and we would expect to pick up our fair share. But it is not a significant factor either in our results or in our guidance.  And Pete, I'll pass it, the re-evaluation comment over to you.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Their is some buzz that may indeed happen. It's just buzz as far as I'm concerned at this point in time, and we have seen roughly a 3.5%, 4% strengthening of the RMB over the last year the first quarter 2011 versus 2010 and indeed happens, it would be ben
componenttext: Their is some buzz that may indeed happen. It's just buzz as far as I'm concerned at this point in time, and we have seen roughly a 3.5%, 4% strengthening of the RMB over the last year the first quarter 2011 versus 2010 and indeed happens, it would be beneficial to our bottom line in terms of our dollar reported financials.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Vincent Andrews of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Vincent Andrews of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask your, your commentary, 2 things struck me, one, you just seem to have a very bullish trip through China; and 2, you prefaced 50 cities this year with at least. So I'm just wondering if on the margin, there's any sort of acceleration in
componenttext: Just wanted to ask your, your commentary, 2 things struck me, one, you just seem to have a very bullish trip through China; and 2, you prefaced 50 cities this year with at least. So I'm just wondering if on the margin, there's any sort of acceleration in your plans to expand in China?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: We haven't made a decision at this point to go beyond the 50 cities this year. But with the momentum that we've reported today, we'll clearly be looking for additional opportunities to invest and we're certainly be talking to our general management team i
componenttext: We haven't made a decision at this point to go beyond the 50 cities this year. But with the momentum that we've reported today, we'll clearly be looking for additional opportunities to invest and we're certainly be talking to our general management team in China to see whether they feel that they would be able to execute flawlessly in a greater number of cities. As you know, they take a very disciplined approach to that, and we will not expand that number unless we're absolutely confident of our ability to be successful in all of the cities in which we operate. You're right, I was struck in my visit. I spent many years living in Asia, I've actually been in China market 50x by I haven't been to a number of these so-called secondary cities. And I was absolutely struck not only by their size, by their quality of infrastructure, by the obvious economic activity but also by the rapid momentum of the international brands in our categories and most particularly of course, our own brands. Most surprisingly, parents in those cities aspire just as parents in the bigger cities, they aspire for their children to be successful in life and nutrition plays a critical role in that. And they are rapidly entering the middle class, and therefore are able to afford a product for the several years. I was reassured that our strategy was right, and I was also reassured that our confidence in sustainable growth was well placed.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: So maybe just a follow up, is it fair to say that there's some opportunity to grow modestly beyond the 50 cities this year, but you might be thinking about accelerating penetration in the out years, and you might need to think about whether you up the siz
componenttext: So maybe just a follow up, is it fair to say that there's some opportunity to grow modestly beyond the 50 cities this year, but you might be thinking about accelerating penetration in the out years, and you might need to think about whether you up the size of the overall investment and maybe staffing and so forth?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I thank that's fair, yes.
componenttext: I thank that's fair, yes.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
